My family loves coming here for their dim sum!  They renovated recently and the place just looks gorgeous!  Everything is nice and clean, fresh and inviting.  They did an excellent job!

Ladies man the carts but you can also try and order with a server as well.  The carts come around quite a bit so just be a little patient if you don't see what you wanted in the first round of ladies going by.  

Some things we usually order:
Steamed and baked pork buns
Small spare ribs
Beef tendon
Beef stomach lining (not sure what it's called in English)
Congee
Shumai
Beef balls
Har gow crystal shrimp dumpling
Calms in black bean sauce
Egg tarts
Turnip cakes 
Shrimp in rice noodle with lots of sauce
Fried taro balls
Tofu pudding 

Oh man, I'm getting hungry thinking of all that food! 
It's all so tasty!

Terrible service!! Waited 40 minutes just for WATER to be served. Our soup was served and we still had no water. We constantly asked, but they never brought any water out to our table even after our entres arrived. We received water after an hour when we were eating our main course. When we got our water they did no refill our water until we were about to leave. Servers had terrible attitudes from the start. Not friendly. The food was cold by the time it reached our table. Very oily. Rice was hard. They were also out of many food choices such as, soy chicken, clams, shrimp, and desserts. The only dessert they had available was sesame balls.

Quick run through review...

Dim sum in Vegas?  Okay!!! :D 

This restaurant is off the strip at the Gold Coast Casino.  The restaurant itself is on the actual casino floor with kind of limited seating so expect to wait unless you're lucky.  

Overall the dim sum is pretty standard when it comes to dim sum, couldn't complain in the taste or MSG overdose afterwards.  I just don't remember if they had my favorite chili paste Sambal Oelek there or not, they may might have had the regular chili oil, which IMO is not the freaking same!  (So if any Asian restaurant owners/managers are reading this please read carefully....Sambal Oelek chili paste can not be substituted with chili oil or any other brand!  Damnamit.)  

Although....one thing that I did enjoy over here specifically was their jellyfish during dim sum hours.  Idk, either the places I go to don't offer jellyfish at dim sum or I just barely missed the very last portion to some lucky sonofabitch.  :/  Other than the jellyfish, their name 'Ping Pang Pong' and that its in Vegas... nothing really stands out to me as I can have the same at any one of the numerous dim sum restaurants in Cali.  Nice place to check out nonetheless if you suddenly have a craving attack for dim sum and the 'Asian' foods at the buffets aren't satiating that craving.

We came by for dinner in this restaurant that was advertised at some point as the best Chinese restaurant in Vegas.  It's located in the older Gold Coast Casino, is a bit rundown but with authentic and low priced servings.  We had a nice beef satay with pineapples and enoki mushrooms (more Hawaiian than traditional Cantonese).  We also had a disappointing clay pot with ginger mushroom chicken.  The rice was flavorful, but there was no ginger, barely any mushrooms, and a lot of bony chicken scraps.  You can also have a Heineken here for $3.50.  Overall, ok for the price, but I suspect it can probably be a better place than what we experienced.   Service was also a bit poor, with no water refills, and it took a while for the rice pot to appear.

Purposely made a trip here because of all the reviews and "best Chinese food" title this place has.  Be aware that this restaurant is located within the Gold Coast hotel. The place doesn't have walls blocking the smoke coming from the casino and I didn't appreciate inhaling smoke while eating. I asked if I can be moved to a more inner location in my desperate attempt to get away from the smoke but the lady said there isn't anywhere she could move me even though I clearly saw many empty tables. Food was subpar but perhaps that's because I was hyped up by previous reviews. But this place gets two stars for fast service and the price.

I must admit, I had high expectations of this restaurant, as I had read it had one some awards. 
It wasn't bad, but it was nothing I would ever go out of my way for again. 
The hot and sour soup was extremely bland.  My Thai iced tea was ok, but just average.
My entree of Dragon Well Shrimp, was very good, and the overall service was very attentive.  
By comparison, Joyful House, which is nearby, is far superior to Ping Pang Pong.  I'd give it 3.25 stars, if there was such a rating.

Food was o.k.  We went here at 130pm so food wasn't as fresh as we wanted ( as they serve dim sum up until 3pm.)  

Temperture of food could have been hotter, but the flavor was there.  Not the best ,but not the worst, just ok.

We stumbled upon this restaurant by accident, and I am happy that we did.  The restaurant has an open, modern feel.  My friend and I took a seat at the counter, where we could get a good look at the chefs preparing the food.  I ordered the Honey Walnut prawns, and it may have been the finest Chinese food I've had in my life.  Practically orgasmic.  I was disappointed that I found this restaurant on my final night in town, or I would have gone back for more the next day.   It will certainly have a spot on my Vegas itineraries in the future.

Pretty good dim sum. Service is spotty though. Like many restaurants in Vegas, it's situated in a casino. I really dislike that as you have to make way thru all the smokers inside. Also, sitting near the outside of the restaurant is awkward because the ppl gambling and walking by just stare at your food. Other than that, it's a decent place for dim sum in Vegas.
This is my go to place when in Vegas for dim sum. The restaurant just got revamped and is very modern. I thought some of the menu prices went up a bit but the portions are generous.

Good prices, large portions, darn good food. Best if you are not in a hurry and have 2 or more hungry people. It is located inside the Gold Coast Casino, off Flamingo not far from the strip. 

I believe the whole restaurant closes for about an hour around 3pm. I would call to make sure it's open if close to 3pm. Gold Coast number is 702-367-7111

I took a star off for service. I've came here about 100 times over the last decade so clearly I like this place but the service should be better in my opinion. Sometimes the service is okay but other times it takes awhile just to get seated and you gotta wave them down to get refills. To give them credit many of the staff members are very kind and work hard.

Give them a try for sure, enjoy.

Having given up on Dim Sum upon my move to Las Vegas six years ago, I had done all my mourning of not being able to drive to Monterey Park from West LA for a Sunday post-clubbing ritual.  I was not expecting much when I arrived at Ping Pang Pong this past weekend, but began to fan little fires of hopes when I saw a restaurant filled with Chinese people and outfitted with a long line also filled with Chinese people.

When they served us a steaming pot of Chinese red tea (forget the stereotypical Jasmine green), my hopes went from little flames to a pretty sizable campfire.  When the cart arrived and I had to explain to the Chinese cart-tender lady what I was looking for since she only spoke marginal English, I felt like I traveled through space and was suddenly in Arcadia.  

My favorites, Siu Mai and Har Gow, more than passed the test.  Siu Mai was surprisingly topped with fish eggs, which added a much-welcomed dynamic in texture.  Har Gow was delicious due to fresh shrimp fillings and a properly-made dough that didn't dry up after five minutes on the cart like the other Vegas Dim Sum joints.  My new adventure, Rice Paper-Wrapped Youtiao (Chinese fried bread stick) filled with Pork, was a perfect combination of tastes, textures, and ingredients. 

Our late arrival cost me my Dim Sum must-have: egg tarts; which provides me with a good reason to come back and visit this Sunday.  In the future, I will no longer avoid restaurants that are in funky casinos like the Gold Coast.  I could be missing out on a lot of yummy egg tarts.
A really nice place for late night Chinese food. But the dim sum is not on the menu. Ask them what they have.
I've eaten dim sum around the world and Ping Pang Pong is right up there with the best of them.  The service was perfect and the food was delicious! We shall return!

Maybe it's because I'm from California. Maybe it's because I'm used to Chinatown in San Francisco being a 15 minute bus ride away.

But when I'm handed a 16 dollar check for three small pork buns, two teas and two plates of small potstickers I gasp.

Because in Chinatown, heck, in any Dim Sum place I've been to in the last five years, that is outlandishly priced.

But hey, maybe all Dim Sum makers decided to up the price all at once and no one told me. Maybe it's just Nevada. No? Just triple P?

Good to know.

The service was good for cart Dim Sum, but again, we didn't revisit during our trip due to the price.

If we return we'll most likely skip it. I'd rather head to TGIF and get a huge place of food for less than that.

If you are looking for good chinese food. Ping pang pong is one of the best chinese restaurant in town, I had a steamed cantonese Princess chicken and Stir fried Lobster with ginger. it was delicious. I am looking forward to back there again.

My favorite Chinese restaurant in Las Vegas! I've lived here for 11 years before discovering this place... I can't believe I've been missing out. I ordered pan fried noodles, spicy pork chop, beef and broccoli, and fried rice. Everything was so tasty and extremely fresh.

I've also placed take out orders and the food is just as yummy!

I love the crispy half chicken from Ping Pang Pong.. Only thing is every second time I come here it's been sold out! We've had to eat the half roast duck instead (also tasty), Kung Pao Chicken (yes I'm dating a white guy ;) We've had pretty good service everytime we've been here and also manage to get a table straight away. Most of the time we eat between 12 and 3am so they usually run out of the crispy chicken by then. Once we came at 7pm and the crispy chicken came out 5 minutes after we ordered it but it wasn't even crispy. The other 3 times it's been great. We like it spicy. 

Dishes we don't like: hot and sour soup. It's not hot or sour... Just big. Wrinkly string beans - sounds exactly like what it is - wrinkly string beans, not the yummiest vege choice! 

Dishes that are average: won ton noodle soup - it's also massive and has lots of veges, chicken feet - flavour is ok. 

Dishes that we like - crispy chicken, pepper beef medallions,roast duck, Kung Pao chicken, Singapore noodles, prawn dumplings, Chinese brocolli. 

Will we be back?  Yes!

Located inside the Gold Coast Casino, I did not expect to be pleased with the dinner here.  In fact, when I first heard the name, I laughed.  I laugh no more.  

We went in a group of 5 people on a Saturday evening.  It was only lightly crowded and we were seated relatively quickly.  

The plates have generous proportions, so a plate per person in the group is just enough to get you full.  We ordered: Wrinkled Green Beans, Chow Fun (or Beef Flat Noodle as they called it), Rosted Duck, Pineapple beef with Mushrooms and Lamb.

Everything we ordered was what you would expect from a "legit" Chinese restaurant.  I would go into detail about each of them, but quite honestly, it was a flurry of amazing flavor that I cannot do justice to describe, but I can definitely say, you HAVE to go try it.

The only reason they lost a star was the customer service.  It's not that the customer service was bad, but it wasn't very good.  It took two or three times to get water and rice, our last two plates were brought our after we were almost done with the first three, and they were not very attentive.

Overall, a MUST TRY.  :D The food makes up for the eh customer service.

Still some of the best dim sum around. Wide variety to choose from. Served from rolling carts   Get there early since it can get real busy. The new location in theGold Coast  is light years better than the old one

I have been here about a dozen times over few years. I would rate the food 4 stars but the service is at best 2 stars, resulting in my 3 star rating for this popular Cantonese restaurant inside the Gold Coast.

The most authentic Chinese restaurant ever. This place serves a whole variety of Chinese food! It is the only place I go to when I stop by Las Vegas. On weekends they serve dim sum, so come early and expect a line cause there will be many others waiting for service to start. 
If you gamble here in this casino, you get comps for this restaurant which is a bonus.
Impressive prices, authentic Chinese food with a few Taiwanese flares... and, attentive service. We're no longer driving to Chinatown when we're in Vegas - we're coming here. Great spot!

Located off strip but hey, they have good sit down dim sum if you're tired of the good old American type breakfast (buffets) on the strip.

All the ladies who served us were nice. They have a pretty good selection in the various carts that go around. The flavors aren't bad either.

The prices are crazy cheap. We ordered around 20 items and the bill is under $100.

Orchid Garden is a thing of the past. Ping Pang Pong's dim sum is far superior!

I would much prefer coming here because of the nicer ambiance and better quality food. Seems like Orchid is going downhill for my taste. They serve everything here for what is seemingly cheaper and better tasting. Word to the wise though, as with all dim sum places, come well before 1:30pm or else they'll be fresh out of everything. They refused to make any more dim sum items after that point.

we went there as a group of 10, called 2 hours in advance to book a table thought it might not be an seats for a large group like us. So I have called in and asking to book a seat said we will be there around 8. the lady who answer the phone said they have plenty of seats and no need to reserve. Then the next thing you know, we spend 30 minutes waiting at the line because we got told don't have any table for us. 

* Food was an ok. no much different compare to the restaurant I had at New York. 

* Waitress who was working on our table was giving us  dirty look. for ordering too much food and beer?

* Manager was super nice and super helpful. we ran out beer, trying to asking for more, she helped us ordering beers from their supplier with minutes.
I will be back here to give it another try.
Delicious and authentic dishes mostly so .. and the setting is just like many traditional dim sum restaurants with nice interior design n architecture
Love coming here!  Food is always good, Mongolian beef, Kung pow chicken and fried rice are our go to dishes, consistently good.  Service was good as well.

Worst Expierence ever! The food was horrible. The chicken fried rice was hard. The texture on the shrimp balls and bbq pork was inedibale. The calamari was soggy. I asked to speak with a manager ( which I rarely do ) and the response was not as one would expect. The manager and the server did not say anything he just simply removed those iteams and brought back the bill.
Decent place for a sit-down meal late night. Had wor wonton soup which had a nice flavorful broth. The veggie spring rolls, however, were not so great.

I've eaten here a few times. First time I went it was horrible. We ended up walking out. But I gave it another try. The food is really good and the prices are very reasonable. Dim sum here is as good as it gets in Vegas. One of the few Chinese restaurants I'll go to in Vegas.

Excellent food , good fast service, reasonable priced, not  crowded on a Wednesday morning. Great desert - yang Zhi Gan Lu and shuang pi nai.
Five star

Let's go to PING PANG PONG! Who would have thought this place is so good! This is seriously one of the hidden gems in vegas.  It's tucked in Gold Coast and it has really good dim sum.  They have the dessert - mango + pomelo which is so hard to find.  This is pure comfort food in vegas.  I love it!!!! It's clean and the decor is really nice.

Ping Pang Pong. Ping Pang Pong. Ping Pang Pong. What a fun sounding name to say over & over.
Wow! Can't believe it's almost a year since the first time I found out about this place through a friend. This time around, we made sure this was the first stop we made in LV to satisfy our huge appetite. Warning: get here early to avoid the long lines of people trying to get some shrimp balls. 
As soon as the host directs you to your seat, be prepared to be asked if you're interested with plate after plate of dim sum & other Chinese concoctions. Items are not priced the same, obviously, so it's a guessing game how much they will charge you at the end of your meal (although they do stamp your order summary with some item/menu codes like in other dim sum places) but it really doesn't matter because the food is good any time of the day. Try the almond coated shrimp & shrimp balls on green bell pepper with black bean sauce with any of their special fried rice. The flavor lingers in your mouth like white on rice. Lol, rice coz I'm Asian. Lots of yummy things here & there; yummy things are everywhere! Order a glass of Thai iced tea or some hot tea to wash out the after taste. Sesame balls are always good to close out a filling meal. Got my full meal, & I was one satisfied customer.

This place is a little pricier when compared to local places in town. Orange chicken is 5/5, so are the wrinkled green beans. They charge 75 cents for a bowl of rice. Hot tea is complimentary :). Had to knock off 2 starts due to service being nonexistent. The busboy only came around once to refill our water. As for the server, he disappeared. Would I come back? Probably not.

We've been here both during regular dining hours and during dim sum. Service is definitely a huge thumbs down. They take your drink order and food order fairly quick. But after that the server is nowhere to be found! You have to hunt the server down before they come to refill your drinks or to see if you need anything else (like napkins, utensils, etc.) I find that to be VERY annoying. They seem pretty annoyed when you ask them something too. Um, if I wanted to serve myself and prepare din on my own... I would have just ate at home. They need to clean this place up too. Is disgustingly dirty. I watched them "wash" their plates. This man just rinsed the plates with boiling, hot water. Omg, ew. 

One star is for their food. It comes out hot and fresh. Only thing I will not complain about. Haha!

This place has the best dim sum we've tried since we've been in Vegas. Several of our friends recommended it and we were happy to oblige. Not to mention, it's right down the street from our home. It's best to go during lunch as they serve up all the best dim sum dishes. The prices are pretty good too. For two of us we spent less than $50 with tip included. Not bad for 8 dim sum dishes. I would recommend the steamed char siu bao, shrimp dumplings, shu mai, choy sum, and walnut shrimp. All the fried rice I've tried here has been good so take your pick. 

This place is usually packed all the time so be prepared to wait or go early to get a good place in line. Service can sometimes be lacking as they seem to not have enough servers who can take your order. Many of the workers do not speak English and therefore will not take orders from customers.

This restaurant foods is good service is nice and you get food so fast also big portion (I can't done it lol)

But something I wanna tell Restaurant is about
Inside restaurant so many people talking so loud and the floor inside restaurant so dirty (a lot a food) you should clean before costumer coming in. And the time i going not busy but you take me to dirty area.
Although the place is small, the dim sum is pretty good to me. They have a good selection for dessert. Not much of the regular dishes, but the taste was pretty good.

I had read the reviews for Ping Pang Pong and although the food was always rated highly, the service was considered poor.

The food is excellent; the service was as good as it gets, the employees were friendly and concerned of our satisfaction.

Great dinner.

I've been coming here for over 15 years. Best Hong-Hong style cuisine in Vegas, and my go to place for dim sum. 
Service is surprisingly good for a Chinese restaurant, and I also feel like the bussers are even more accommodating than the servers here. 
Everything I've tried from their combination fried rice, salt and pepper shrimp, mapo tofu, Mongolian beef, kung pao chicken, seafood pan fried noodles, to their live crab with XO sauce, has been really good. 
The only thing that bothers me about this place is the cigarette smell that diffuses into the restaurant from the slot machine area. I don't need to be breathing in secondhand smoke when my arteries are already getting clogged from all the oil and fat. Ya dig?

I think if you like seafood and dim sum you will like this place. Unfortunately I don't like either.  I ordered beef with broccoli and the beef was tough as was the broccoli but what really annoyed me is I could taste seafood in my food like they cooked my beef in the same pan as fish or some other type of seafood. I cannot stand the smell or taste of seafood and can detect the tiniest amount! Also the smell from the dim sum cart is appalling.

Despite the over-the-top cheesy name, the food is delicious! We ordered the shiimai dumpling, chicken feet, clams, and salt and pepper pork. Everything was GREAT and we cleared every plate! It's off of the strip and you have to take a cab to get to the dingy casino it's in, but it's well worth it. The service sucks but the food was so good that  I couldn't even be mad. Best part is that it's open till 3am so you can get your drunk-Chinese-food on!

Love coming here with my family, they discovered this Chinese spot!!! This is prob one of the best Chinese places in Vegas. It's always busy! Though the service should be a lot better but I guess that's typical at any Chinese/Asian restaurant you go to. You can never go wrong with your order everything is made to please.

We went to this restaurant early around 10 in the morning, we ordered har kaouw , shiu Mai, they are yummy, chicken feet was well cook and tender, bi tan congee delicious and fresh, put some soy sauce a little bit to make it perfect. The service is good, the waitress replaced my plates 2 times maybe because it was early and not many people. The price is reasonable considering this is in Vegas, 9 items for 25.90 even cheaper than the one in Denver. Two thumbs up, definitely it will be first place to visit next time to Vegas.

I surprised my family by taking them here and pigging out at this dim sum place that I had discovered on my last trip.  The dim sum is surprisingly good and they have most of the stuff that we are familiar with whenever we go...

They charge 50 cents per person for tea which is what a lot of places do but I still consider that outrageous since I'm old school and such a practice was never used (*sigh*)...

Although it's not Alhambra/Monterey Park cheap, (2) $2.18 for dim sum type A, (11) $2.88 for dim sum type B, (4) $3.88 for dim sum type C, and $5.88 for (1) dim sum type D plus the $2 for tea still came out to be less than $60 -- A REAL BARGAIN considering where we are...

We were stuffed and happy for our return trip back to LA.  I would come back again...

Really enjoyed ordering different dishes family style and sharing. We liked the pork belly in clay pot, and an interesting dish with something called "wood ear mushrooms".  

There are always a lot of chinese people here, just like their other restaurant Noodle Exchange, which is a good sign that the food is authentic/good. Just do not order the dim sum.. it was not fresh and seems like an afterthought.
My son is hooked.  He definitely wants to go back here and have their calamari.

Talk about a popular dim sum place! My family has loved this restaurant for a few years, but this was my first time trying it, so I was excited. We tried to get here by 9:45am so we could get in for the first seating at 10, but unfortunately we missed it so needed to wait 45 min or so as groups started to leave. And there continued to be a long line. 

Haha, I'm impressed by the efficient design!
The tables are arranged in a circle so that carts can go around to the tables and then replenish at the kitchen. Unfortunately since we were at the beginning of the second seating, there weren't many items we often like (chicken feet, har gao, siu mai) since they ran out. Fortunately, we got them as we were finishing up.

I really enjoyed something that seemed like shrimp tempura wrapped in funn. It was delicious! I also liked the eggplant shrimp (generous amount of shrimp inside) and roast pork. I also love gailan, and I appreciated that the sauce was on the side so I could control how salty I wanted it.

The baked char siu bao could've been softer, though, and filled with more meat. The butter buns were filled with lots of butter, though they could have been warmer and softer.

The service was generally good and some of the servers even smiled. If you're family with dim sum restaurants, you know that's rare.

I enjoyed Ping Pang Pong and would return again. Most of the customers were Chinese and other Asian, so you know the experience is really Chinese!

This review is for 3.5 stars.

I came here on a week night at about 6pm looking for some good Chinese food.  Ping Pang Pong is located in the Gold Coast so I expected the price to be a bit higher than normal but was actually pleased as it was very consistent with other sit-down Chinese restaurants in town.  

The portions are very big here and very fresh.  They are known for their dim sum so I had to at least try some of their dinner dim sum to give a true review.  I had the pork buns dim sum, lettuce cups, and BBQ pork ribs.  Add in a few drinks and the bill came out to $44 after tax.  The pork bun was just eh.  I usually like the steamed bun but this came with a dessert-type of crust which caught me off guard.  Tasty innards, but not much going on in the way of a dish.  The lettuce cups were quite tasty and I actually recommend them as a nice appetizer.  Finally, the BBQ ribs were average - still can't find an authentic Chinese BBQ char siu in town.  The meat was good but not much flavor.  And the bone was so large that there wasn't much meat on each cutlet (though there were many ribs on the plate).  The dish came with some boiled peanuts which were a nice addition to the meal.  

Service was all over the place.  I'm not sure if it was busy or what but the waitress would disappear and then show up and take 6 orders before returning to the kitchen.  So your order wouldn't be placed immediately, rather you have to wait until her rounds were up.  Very weird way of doing business but the food came out quickly and we were in and out quickly after just waiting a long time to place the order.

Ping Pang Pong is good Chinese food.  I prefer local when trying Asian cuisine in this town so I won't be back, but if you are staying at Gold Coast or nearby and don't have a car, and are craving non-American Chinese, then give this location a try.

Good food at a good price. The amount of food is also very generous. Always get seated quickly and attended also. The honey walnut shrimp is the best. Hands down. Fried rice is good. The food is really tasty. It only sucks because depending on the table, you could smell the smoke from the casino. I don't understand why they didn't just built walls around it. It's good tho. Try em out.

Poor customer service as we waited for 30 mins for the server to return our check. I can only vouch they have decent dim sum selections but it was hard to be patient with their service while our phones' receptions never work in this restaurant. Hope another place would open up to take over in this town with good customer services.

Dim Sum in Vegas is a great thing.

Problem is these idiots don't know how to sit people in order. Stood in line for 30 mins while people behind was seated first because they had bigger parties. First come first serve numb nutts.

Food was decent, but shu mai never came our way wtf?

They should call this place Ping Pang Pow, because I was about to slap the dam mgr upside his fat head.

I gave a 20% tip anyways, our server was ok and I am not a monster.

ok first of all... lets just start out by saying I am from LA... and lucky for me we have Chinatown and the entire San Gabriel Valley a.k.a. China! Now maybe Vegas just doesn't have too many authentic chinese restaurants but damn this was the worst dim sum I have ever had in my life! My friend took me there 2 weeks ago and well the name kinda threw me off to begin with but once I tried the shu mai... damn it was over! I didnt want to try anything else. The simplest dim sum and yet they couldnt even get it right. The beefballs were too overcooked too!  Even the tiny little pork buns were to run from. How does this place stay in business? But then again maybe they are catering to a different crowd. What really struck me as weird was the fact the place was full of asians! I mean, is this suppose to be as good as it gets in Vegas for dim sum? If so, I'd rather stop by a trader joes and pick up a pack of frozen shu mais. You will have much better luck going to the frozen food aisle at a supermarket for good dim sum. Oh one more thing.. horrible service. The employees are literally fresh off the boat! I guess thats the only thing authentic about this place, their workers! hahahaha Trust me when I say I will never come back here or recommend this to another soul.. unless i hated them and wanted to waste their money! =D
One of the best place to take the family. Try the salt&pepper pork chops and orange chicken. So much to choose from. A popular spot here in Vegas. Service always great every time.

I only eat here for Dimsum. I like the atmosphere open to the casino floor. Try the flowers tea, so refreshing. The food is hot and yummy. Long wait line in the weekend. Havent tried dimsum on the strip yet, here is the best dimsum in vegas to me so far.

we have been coming here since moving from nyc in 93.  we feel its one of the better chinese restaurant here in town.  the food is authentic and fresh. The new dining room is able to accommodate more customers so the wait time is not too long as it used to be in the old setting.  we had dim sum a few days ago and found it to be quite gd the dim sum was warm and fresh.  
The servers were all very helpful.  It is the place to have dim sum

No matter how badly I rate this sorry excuse of an establishment, it won't make a difference because it has a cherry location and will always have customers no matter what.

That being said, the food was mediocre and the customer service was the worst I've encountered in this city.

I can't go into details about my experience without sounding like a bigot, so I'll just say this restaurant is a disappointment.

Dim Sum restaurant hidden @ Gold Coast.  If you are craving good dim sum Pin Pang Pong is the place to go.  They have a mediorcre selection of dim sum, probably more on the weekends.  The wait isn't too bad, but if they can have a greater selection of dim sum it would be better.

This place to me is not all that great dim sum I've had better. The only thing that is good here is the walnut shrimp and the portions is great enough for a family of 5. 

The time I came it didn't seem like the dim sum carts wanted to go to the other side of the restaurant. When you asked what it was in the cart the cart lady  had a hard time speaking english. Which was a boo for them.  How can you serve someone when you can't even tell them what it is.  Service is whack... can't get water or the check. FAIL.. 

So thank you for the yummie walnut shrimp but no thank you for not giving me my check when I asked for it 3 times.

A very authentic Cantonese restaurant? My husband and I enjoyed a midnight meal having veggies, chicken and congees. The next day we returned to dine on their scrumptious dim sum . The service is excellent add one more excuse to Las Vegas soon .

My parents and I went there for lunch on a Monday. The dim sum that they serve is quite tasty. The variety, however, leaves quite a bit to be desired. 

Mom enjoyed the chicken feet, dad the baked pork buns (I thought it was a bit too sweet). We also had har gow, pork ribs (yum!), red bean gelatin dessert (this was good), red bean buns (my dad was desperate for food by this time). Service was good - prompt removal of plates, refilling of tea pot. 

It's super noisy there. Near impossible to have a conversation across the table. This is most likely a Las Vegas casino complaint (?), but the entire restaurant smelled like an ashtray. I'm sensitive to smoke, so this was a less-than ideal eating situation. 

The bill, for three people (two elderly people in their 80s and one female) was $60. That is stratospherically high for people who don't eat much. And the smell. It was awful. Will not be visiting again.

As I have said before.... I LOVE this place.. best dim sum ever...! 
However... now that they have settled into the new location.. they raised their prices fairly substantially! My morning dim sum and wonton soup routine has raised from $35 per session to $42!!! Ouch!!!

dont even try the thai tea! it was super nasty! tasted like watered down thai tea... 

however some dishes were excellent, but most were decent. 

must try the egg custard dessert thing, soo good!!

Dim Sum on a Sunday Morning in Vegas?  Sure why not.  We've been to other places and wanted to give this place a try.  

We were seated by the kitchen area where the food comes out however they keep missing us until the end of their rounds.  It seemed like their pathway needs to be improved somehow.  

There were good selections and the food is mediocre.  I'll still come and eat here if I'm in the area.
This place is so cute.  Pretty decent food, great atmosphere.  The front and back of the house are clean and the staff are super friendly.

The best dim sum in Las Vegas for a very reasonable price. Food is amazing, best bbq pork buns and shrimp noodles. Food comes fast and is very fresh. Five stars for the food alone. Need to know what the place is - be prepared for bad service, very long lines, and a lot of people.

My wife and I stayed at Gold Coast and after a strong Vegas first night, found ourselves looking for breakfast/lunch around noon. After some deliberation, we decided to check this place out. A number of Chinese employees and clientele encouraged us, so we got a table and waited for the carts. Surprisingly, for dim sum in a Vegas casino, pretty good! We have done NBC in Monterey Park and hold that as the standard. If NBC is a 10, this is an 8.5. Char Siu Bao were tasty but small, the dumplings were very good, as were the shu mai. If you need a dim sum fix near the strip, check it out. Oh and the price is very fair, $23 for two of us and we were stuffed.
Hands down the best Chinese for the price. Never had it  fresh and hot since I always get take out. A must try for locals.

My family always comes here for dinner, so unfortunately we haven't tried the dim sum. Here are my reviews for the entrees we order every time we go there:

Seabass hotpot: this is a hit or miss. Sometimes the seabass is awesomely delicious and sometimes I wonder if it is the same dish I ordered the last time. Overall, it's our favorite thing to order on the menu.

Shrimp fried rice: it's nearly impossible to mess up fried rice unless you tried really hard. In this case, you would dishona our famiry!!! The shrimp is big and not the small wimpy dried ones a lot of the other places give. Can't go wrong if you want a rice dish.

Roasted duck: the skin is gooey, not crispy as I want it. There is very little meat on it. I was a bit disappointed in this one..

Chow fun (dry): this dish is like Asian spaghetti. I like the fresh sprouts that they use and the noodles are always delicious.

Tomato onion scallops: yuck! I love scallops and decided to order this for the first time. There was so much sweet and sour dressing on it, it was like drinking that thing. Ugh... I expected it to be fried scallops with fresh tomatoes and onions, but i guess I was wrong on this dish. Just thinking about this dish gives me horrible flashbacks and makes me want to gag. No beuno!!!!

Service: usually really quick, but a few times we waited forever or they forgot our order.. The price is fairly cheap for the amount of food you get. I noticed that you get so much more food if you take it to go than eating there. :)

Don't order to go. I ordered a to go order right when they opened. Was told 25 to 35 minutes. It took them one hour 10 minutes for s fried rice, noodle dish, and some pork buns. People who sat down were done and walking around the casino faster. Other people got thier to go orders faster. The food it tight, but the service lacks. I regret leaving a tip. They sure did not earn it.

Edit: when I got home the food was worse. Chicken fried rice was undercooked, looked like it had boilednl chicken in it, the pork buns were odd. They had sugar cookies baked into the tops? The only thing they got right was the noodles. Now my only regret is that I cant give them negative stars.

When I'm in Vegas I usually do steaks or buffets. Sometimes BBQ and burgers. Never thought I'd go dim sum in Vegas... and never ever did I think I'd like it. Surprise surprise!!! Did it and it was delightfully good.
The best dim sum I have ever had in US. Even better than those in Bay Area, NYC and LA. Be prepared for long waits because seats are limited.

Pretty good dimsum at affordable prices.  

Selection is limited if you want beancurd wrap.  

We came here at 11am on Sunday morning and did not really have to wait.  Rolling carts at two sections.

Negative - facing the casino so you breathe the smoke.

Fish eel soup was good.  $9/bowl.

I've been to a few dim sum places in Vegas but this one is by far the best. Been coming here every time I visit now and have not been disappointed. Hard to imagine authentic dim sum in a casino but I found it better than some places in china town.

Price is reasonable and never had to wait more than two minutes to be seated. 

Good to take friends, dates (who like dim sum), coworkers and customers.

Make sure to try the congee (rice porridge with pork)

Ping Pang Pong. The food is great the service is horrible.

You know a chinese place is great when the restaurant is full of Asian people! Almost everything is very tasty but do expect it to be very heavy and oily/saucy. That might be the thing that makes this place great. 

My only complaint is that the servers always seem like they are in a bad mood and doing you a favor.

Wow, probably one of the best dim sum restaurants in Vegas! This restaurant is located inside a hotel. We tried to call and make reservations beforehand because some of the reviews talked about having to wait a long time. However they only accept reservations for parties of 10 or more. For a group of 3, we only had to wait about 10 minutes on a Sunday afternoon.

The interior of the restaurant is clean, spacious, and looks new. Once we got seated, there were immediately 3 carts that came by, so we were able to get food right away. The carts consistently came by our table so we never had to chase anyone down for food. Tea is $1 per person. The food is great here, however the dishes are a little bit more expensive for dim sum. For example, we got a plate of egg tarts which cost $4.88 per plate. And the egg tarts had 2 per plate instead of 3. Overall, I highly recommend this dim sum restaurant if you don't mind spending a little more!

Love!! Chinese is my favorite food and this place is a real treat. We made the trip from the strip to this restaurant and I'm so glad I did! The servers had some trouble understanding our English, but they were so sweet it didn't matter. The potstickers were a favorite - so juicy when I cut into them the splattered all over my shirt so consider yourself warned.

The Jasmine tea was perfect along side the Dim Sum!! Every food I tried was fresh and well prepared. It felt as if I were dining in Hong Kong. That is wonderful! Many other restaurants in town fall short on authenticity. This is a great restaurant and the service is very attentive!! I also loved the egg noodles, really crisp. The spring rolls were nice and the orange beef was superb. I admit, I ordered so much food that I had to take quite a lot home in a couple to go boxes. Hey, but that's a good thing!!! :))

Have to confess, I wasn't expecting much from this place and its goofy name, not to mention it's in a casino. But it was actually really good dinner food. Our relatives brought us takeout from this place and it was pretty amazing. 

Recommendations: 
Chive and shrimp cake -- surprisingly crisp and fresh with plenty of shrimp. 
Crispy shrimp stuffed chicken -- this was amazing. While it feels a bit like Americanized Chinese food, the meat was tender and had a light coating with a sweet garlic-based sauce and sesame seeds
Night market Fried Rice -- Strong basil flavor, tomato based sauce. Unique and definitely different from any fried rice I've had.
Yu Hong (Yu xiang) Eggplant -- pretty typical rendition of this sweet and sour eggplant dish, nothing too unusual...  this dish needs white rice on the side. 

Cons: 
Based on the menu, it's on the pricey side for what it is. 

Can't say anything about the service or the dining experience since I wasn't actually there but the food was definitely excellent.

Avoid this place...do yourself a favor....run to another establishment...now...seriously...7/11/17, Tuesday afternoon, waiting on the to go line for at least 11minutes.  

Then, a team member states she will notify the front that I'm waiting to place my order.  Well, honestly, I don't think that happened because I took the initiative to go to the front team members and indicate that I'd like to place a to go order.  She gives me a menu that indicates dim sum associated with letters.  Then, I ask what do these letters indicate?  After, she hands me another menu with pictures and numbers.  I ask her how does this work?  Then, I asked the other lady at the front how do I know how much the dim sum with the numbers cost?  She indicates that the menu with the dim sum and letters are invalid.  So, the menu with the pics and numbers, how do I know how much the items cost?  She mentions oh just ask me.  

What?  In other words, you could rip me off with no basis?  

Total wait time + ordering + verifying the menu, prices, etc. = ~45min.  

With that said, I highly recommend a revised dim sum menu with correct prices displayed for the customers' and establishments' maximum efficiency, time, ease, respect, and ethics in food service management.  

Plus, I recommend more staff training accommodating those waiting to dine in, to go, and pay their bill because after observing this establishment while waiting for to go service, it seemed like there was a lack of communication between team members that was very obvious, no team work, and lack of organization.  

In conclusion, I highly recommend the general manager, staff, and anyone involved in running this establishment to review training in customer service, food service management 101, and menu development.

The food was good but as with most Asian restaurants service was horrible.  I had to get up twice to ask for the carts to go over to our side of the restaurant.  Seems like the cart pushers have now rhyme or reason to where they push their carts.  They kept circling around the other side where everyone had food already.

This was some great Dim Sum! Everything was fresh, hot and delicious. Service was gracious as well as polite. We didn't have one bad dish.
My biggest complaint? Because we arrived so early, they seemed to only have desserts ready & those kept coming around quite readily in the beginning. They didn't seem to start bringing out the savory dishes til about 15-20 minutes after they opened.
My recommendations? If you arrive early, be patient & wait about 20 minutes til the dishes really start coming out. If not, then show up about 30 minutes after they open, just be prepared to wait.
The challenge? Their Servers are all Chinese, which is great, however with all of the noise, hearing them through the noise & their accents was a challenge.
Definitely a go to spot from now on!

Five stars go out to the Manager Krysty. She was very professional and very customer service oriented. This is one of our favorite Places to eat. Food is always fresh and full flavored. We had a bit of a mixed up with our food and a delay took place but she fixed the problem and was very apologetic and wanted to make sure we were taken care of. She is amazing!

Seating is limited and service is unhurried so expect a long wait at lunch time. Getting in is the hard part-- you stand in line with a crowd of people yelling in various Chinese dialects as they shove, cut, and complain-- all adding authenticity and closely matching my experiences in China.  Another reason for the long wait is, once inside, diners tend to linger. I don't blame them. The food is tasty, hot, and well-varied. All my favorite dim sum dishes were here.  Servers are friendly and I never felt ignored (as I have at other dim sum places).  For about $18 including tip I was able to stuff myself.

  The 40 minute wait to get in was painful but I'm glad I stuck around.

Can't come here for Dim Sum lunch. Way too busy. Wait forever. Although the Dim Sum is excellent. Dinner time is not as busy or crazy. All dinner items on the menu are awesome. The taste and seasonings are perfect. Nothing is too salty or overly spicy. Absolutely perfect food. Full recommendation for dinner.

Absolutely enjoy dining in an atmosphere that reminds me of HongKong as a child vacationing with my Mom & Dad. The wait in the line to get a table and seating is not bothersome as watching the activity in the restaurant and seeing the Chinese cooks in their crisp white chef garbs before chinese woks and hot fire, all viewable in the open cooking area. These Chinese cooks whip up authentic Chinese menu! The food servers there to serve and aid in choosing from the menu and answer meal questions. Authentic Chinese cuisine, in that it is not Americanized Chinese food. From seafood, to vegetables, soups, main meat meals and dessert, it could never been any less filling. Best recommendation is to try each and every entree in the menu. In as much as I return dining in this restaurant located inside the Gold Coast Hotel and Casino of the west side of Entertainment City, I have a constant pick which you may want to try. For starters, savor the taste of Savory Minced Squab and Pork Tenderloin (served with hoisin sauce). A Provincial favorite dish is Double-Braised Scallop Hot Pot (whole seared scallops simmering in garlic oyster sauce served in a sealed clay pot) which is just tasteful. A favorite dish is the Singapore Rice Noodles with a taste of curry that reminds me definitely of SIngapore (with vermicelli. shrimp, BBQ pork, onions). Serve me Duck and it sticks in my palate even after it's off the plate into the tummy filling: Plum-Orange Braised Leg of Duck or the Cantonese Roast Duck (Half). The Lobster and Vermicelli Clay Pot steaming in broth, or the Emperor's Seafood Stew (sun-dried abalone, fish maw with supreme sea cucumber all simmered in flavorful broth) or the Manila Clams with Black Bean Sauce definitely sends me to seafood heaven. Develop a taste for the very appetizingly filling Clay Pot & Congee meals is a definite choice: Ginger Mushroom Chicken Rice or the Sausage Duck Confit Rice. For Rice dishes, I always order Cantonese Curry Beef Brisket Stew, or the Chow Fried Rice (with BBQ pork, green onions and shrimp), or the spicy Night Market Fried Rice (with sliced beef, fresh Thai chilies, diced tomatoes, bean sprouts), or Fu Chow Fried Rice (mixed seafood sauted in a light scallion gravy) or the Pineapple Seafood Fried Rice (which reminds me of being in the islands). A vegetable favorite is Sauted Lotus Root (thinly sliced in an sweet and pungent sauce), or the Snow Pea Leaves with Roasted Garlic. Highly recommend "Dim Sum" as it is for me the best bang for your bucks in this entertainment city! A wide array presented in rolling carts pushed around by chinese-garbed food servers all too willing for passing it on to your table from the dim sum cart. Ready for small eats that leaves you wanting more, go Dim Sum! Dim Sum dining is at lunch time. As I have experienced dining here as often as possible, see for yourself why it's been voted many times as "one of the top 10 Chinese restaurants in America" by Travel + Leisure magazine and "Best Asian Restaurant in Las Vegas" by readers of the Las Vegas Review-Journal! China has never been closer at Ping Pang Pong! Ha, that's a hit!

Loved the dim sum here. Tasted very fresh. Not salty, not oily like other places. I highly recommended this place. 

I should come back for dinner when i'm in the area again.

I recently came here and wow it's like brand new lol they remodeled the place it's much bigger and nicer. We sat and waited for our dim sum to come around seems like they didn't have much to offer. I asked for a few things and they said soon it's coming which it never did lol. Overall service is bad and food never came only had a few choices ate what we can grab and we left

This is the best dim sum in Las Vegas. 

1. Open kitchen. I like to watch people cook and check if they are sanitary. They're doing it right back there. Clean for a Chinese restaurant. 

2. The cart ladies can speak English. They don't just dump the dishes in my table when I point and ask, "what is it?"

3. Food is fresh. They don't give me old food that's been around and rejected by other people. If I want the new batch, they'll give me just that. 

4. Rice is not free. Blahhh. I love rice. They come in a little portion bowl thingy. Their prices are typical for dim sum though. 

5. Food is not as great as LA dim sum, but it still has all of the items I want from a dim sum. 

I recommend you try.

This place sucks ass! I probably would never recommend this place to anyone and would never come back. The service is horrible! This place isn't that big so you would guess the servers would make more frequent trips with their cart; but nope. And when asking for certain items and being told there's no more, you would also think they would place an order for you or something; once again nope. NEVER AGAIN!!!

I never would have thought the Gold Coast Casino and Hotel had such a yummy tasting Dim Sum Restaurant. I happened to arrive just at the right time before 12pm because after I got seated there was a line out the door. Eat a lot of different dishes, all for a cheap price.

Best Dim Sum around period. I'm heading back tomorrow for my second visit on a weeklong vacation. The bbq pork dumplings are awesome here as is most everything. Go hungry and be prepared to eat a lot. The carts of wonderful Chinese food just keep coming.

We've been here both for Dim Sum in the daytime and tried a few of their items at dinner...The food has been pretty solid. I prefer the quality of food here than other places we' ve tried(Cathay House, Orchids Garden)....Give them a try and see what you think....ALOHA!!!

Staff was courteous and fast, ambience was nice and it was good for our large group. We brought in a birthday cake that they served and even brought out their staff to sing happy birthday. Great experience!

Currently this is my favourite Dim Sum in the US. The prices are dirt cheap in comparison to LA/SF/NYC, and the quality is top notch. The servers with the carts are quite pushy, and you'll need to learn to say no and keep looking for what you want, but it's worth it. Also, there can be some serious language barriers at times, but if it looks good it probably is good and eventually you'll learn what everything is. I never miss this place when in Vegas and I suggest you don't either. Even if you don't have a car with you, it's worth the cab ride.

Good authentic Chinese food! Only reason I'm giving it 3 stars is because of the service, you'd think that since this restaurant is located inside a hotel in VEGAS they'd handle diversity well! The food is great, best fried rice in Vegas here, and shrimp cakes are perfection.

There's a line to get into the restaurant. All guests in your party must be present before your party may be seated. It's important to let the hostess know how many people there is in your party. For drinks, they provide complimentary tap water. However, there's a flat fee per person for a pot of Chinese Restaurant Tea. The dim sum was delicious. However, I didn't like how the windows on the dim sum cart weren't very visible. I felt that the dim sum could have been more presentable!

We got the following:

1. A bowl of steamed rice topped with chinese mushroom, diced chicken in bone, and ginger. It was served in a tall wooden bamboo looking container. It came with soy sauce on the side. I felt that the rice was a bit bland. I didn't like how the chicken had small little bones.

2. Eggplant topped with shrimp in black bean sauce. It came in 3. It was tasty but on the oily side.

3. Pan Fried Sticky Rice Cake filled with Red Bean Paste on a round banana leaf. It came in 3. It was crispy on the top, sweet and savory.

4. Steamed Beancurd Wrapped Tofu Ball topped with English Peas, Corn, and Chinese Mushroom.

5. Steamed Crystal Shrimp Dumpling. It came in 4. I liked how there were big pieces of shrimp and no fillers in the dumpling.

6. Steamed Fish Paste Ball, which came in 3, consisted of fish paste, coriander, diced Chinese sausage, topped with a gojiberry, and over a bed of enoki mushroom.

7. Steamed Roast Pork Buns, which came in 3 and were fresh from the oven.

8. Chinese style Crepe filled with crispy dough and shrimp and topped with soy sauce and scallion.

9. Steamed Beef Ball, which came in 3, consisted of beef and parsley, served over a bed of beancurd, and drizzled with A1 sauce.

10. Steamed Sticky Rice with sausage, scallion, egg, and dried shrimp. I was surprised there wasn't any Chinese mushroom.

11. Egg Custard Tart. I liked how the crust was slightly burnt!

Ping Pang Pong is best dim sum place in Vegas except Jasmine in Bellagio. I've lived in Los Angeles for 15 years and I am telling you this is a really good dim sum place but you have to come here early. You have to come here before noon time (they open at 10am) to have most fresh and tasty dim sum. My fav dishes are sausage bao, custard tarts, porridge, pearl rice balls,har gow,scallions and chicken feet.

The only reason can bring me to gold coast hotel is having dim sum at Ping Pang Pong and hot pot at Noodle Exchange. Otherwise I would never step into this hotel because the environment. However I keep coming back here for food twice a month. Now you can figure out how much I enjoy their food :)

My family doesn't really like to go out to Chinese restaurants very often since my dad was once a Chinese chef and knows how to cook dishes very well himself. When we do go out or get take-out however, it's always from 'Ping Pang Pong' (still don't understand the logic of this name choice..). He always raves how this is a really good Chinese restaurant and they cook their dishes with all the right ingredients and proportions. The pricing is very suitable too. You would assume being inside a casino, they would charge more than the actual dish is worth, but the price range is about $6-8 for a good portion of food per dish. 

My dad would be the one to know all the technical stuff with what is a good quality Chinese dish and bad quality. The reason why I know this restaurant really lives up to the 'Best Chinese Restaurant' awards plastered around the entrance is because the traffic that I have seen come in and out of this restaurant, and the number of to-go orders that are bunched up on their large counter space everytime I am here. It's ridiculous! We've had to wait a good 45 minutes for our to-go order (3 dishes) to come out, so my advice is if you're looking for some take-out.. make sure you order way ahead of time of when you expect to actually eat.

Had dimsum the other day and they don't have a wide variety of options but for what they do have, it's superb quality in my opinion! Really loved their turnip cake. Best I've ever had! 

4 instead of 5 stars is just because I wish their floor space was a little larger and had more selection of dimsum items, but as for their quality of food.. 5 stars for sure.

Best dim sum I've ever had in Vegas! I will have to make a point to come here on each Vegas trip! There is a line, but we got there just in time we didn't have to wait too long. They have all my favorite dim sum carts so I'm not complaining there. All so tasty. Didn't try anything off the menu but the dim sum won my heart so... can't wait til next time, Ping Pang Pong! 

Such a cute name. :)

Oh, service was okay. It's Chinese (I'm Chinese) so you know how it goes.

Everyone was raving about Ping Pang Pong, and after a having a good meal at the Noodle Exchange the night before I was looking forward to trying them out. During lunch hours they have Dim Sum, if you love mostly shrimp dishes, then it's for you. I wasn't that thrilled with it, I did check out the lunch menu, but there wasn't anything that jumped out at me, I think I missed the boat on Ping Pang Pong, should have gone during dinner time.

It's always a good sign when you go to a Chinese restaurant and the place is packed with Chinese people and the servers are Chinese and speaking the language.  And wouldn't you know it, Ping Pang Pong has some great dim sum!  So many options, and it's so tasty.  I can't review every single one we tried as there were so many. But they were all good!!  But go early, there is a long line at lunch time.  The line moves, but I wouldn't say it moves fast.   The dim sum place in Rio (KJ's) is a little more on the nicer side, but personally, having been to both I prefer Ping Pang Pong.

My parents love this place for dim sum so we were all dragged here.  At first, we were dim sum in a casino?  Really?  You know what, they serve authentic chinese dim sum.  Actually, I was surprised that the dim sum was pretty good.  I agree with Ed C. some of the sauces seems a little watered down.  

Highlights that I can remember:
The BBQ buns (steamed and baked) were good!
Steamed spareribs were good, a tab bit too spicy for me.
Steamed rice wrapped in green leaves - YUM!
Rice soup with shredded pork and preserved egg - YUM YUM!
Almond tofu dessert - 1 Yum and a Yeah!

This place easily has the worst customer service I have ever experienced in my life. I have heard good things about the food here, & my expectations were high. 

So me & my family arrive, we were brought in. Not sure what to expect being my first time @ this place (may I add how I was excited & actually having a celebration lunch) & immediately they were wheeling around appetizers asking tables what they would like. So confused on how things work here , mainly because nobody told me. Several times I asked for entrees and each time they told me they had no more. 

Never once was I presented a menu, so I literally had a appetizer lunch with no menu  at all, I have never felt so bamboozled & unsatisfied in Chinese food history. LET ME TELL YOU, a bad review from me is very rare, as a matter a fact? This is my first! I hate this place now & I will never recommend this terrible customer service to anybody. 

Also, the manager at the time still wanted me to pay the full price for all the crappy little appetizers that were basically forced upon me. I tried to explain my dissatisfaction & how un pleased I was with never receiving a menu, & she told me the customer is suppose to ask for one!! Where do they do that at!? So I'm automatically suppose to know how procedure goes at this restaurant being my first time there!? Bull crap!!! Never again!! Actually , I'm discrediting this restaurant every chance I get in the future, their mistake for the bs service because I have a great network of people to spread a huge word. Ok, rant over. Screw you PING PANG PONG

The noodle and the chicken was partly cold. And the bum is partly hard partly soft. It looks like it's brought from a Chinese's market and microwaved it. It is unacceptably. And they even include tips already. Like wtf.. your food is cold and how dare you to just put the tip without telling me.

Like many others, we opted for PPP on a random late Vegas night.  The food was alright (went for the veggie noodles) and although better than some other places I've tried, it really didn't hit the spot for me.  Plus, we came on a kind of busy night...? It took quite a while to get seated even though it wasn't too busy looking and a bunch of empty tables available.  Rough night for them?  Maybe.  Food was enticing enough to maybe return for a 2nd round.. hopefully my experience is better next time.

I love to eat dim sum so we decided to try Ping Pang Pong inside the Gold Coast Hotel & Casino. Everything we ate was delicious! My sister and brother in law who drove from Flagstaff, really enjoyed the steamed and baked char sui bau. Ladies come around with their carts full of "small plates". When asking what the items were, I personally had difficulty understanding what they were saying. Just pointing at the dish seemed to work. Egg tarts and sesame seed covered "donuts" were the perfect end to this great meal.

Yes, they have unique dim sum that you don't find in a usual dim sum restaurant, but the quality of the food is not the greatest.  Here, what you pay is what you get. The restaurant itself is pretty small, so we were lucky to get the big round table. Tea is good (we got chrysanthemum ). The staff was nice and they weren't mean like typical Hong Kong staff. However, the Chinese restaurant in Rio has way better dim sum, and the quality is a lot better. 

Here's a summary of what we ordered & what I can recall : 

Chicken wrapped in Lotus Leaf - Only get 1, and it didn't taste fresh/moist. Rice was a little hard.
Sausage Bun - Bun wasn't soft and sausage was not the greatest. 
Chicken Feet - Probably the best thing we ordered - Came with 5 
Ha Gow (wrapped shrimp) - Small - We ordered 2, and 1 came with 4 pcs, and another came with 2 pcs. Inconsistent.
Turnip Cake - OK. Same as everywhere else - A little dry.
Beef rice rolls - OK. Same as everywhere else
Baked Pork Buns - OK.

Saw the signs that said they were voted the #1 best Chinese Restaurant in Las Vegas & they were right!  We all really enjoyed our meal.  
I would definitely recommend this restaurant!

great food!

been here for both dim sum & just a dinner.

its usually REALLY busy & there's almost always a line out the front door. but honestly, its worth the wait.
the prices are very reasonable & you get a lot for your money.


definately a place to take company when you want some good food!
oh and they do close for an hour or so after lunch.
BUT, open until 3am! =)

Came for Dimsum for breakfast on a sunday morning. The line quickly gets long so we arrived a little early so we wouldnt wait long. The way it works for those who have never been is the servers push carts with items, you ask for the item you want, they stamp your paper and at the end you get your bill. Everything we had was delicious especially chrysanthemum flower tea. Its a must.

This place isn't the best dim sum place but its pretty good for the area. This place is rated #1 best dim sum by all the white people and asians seem to like it too. We went for dim sum Sunday at 11am. We got the last table before the long line began! 

Service was really good. Shrimp har-gow was hot, fresh, and tasty. The shrimp noodle was delicious! The steamed pork buns and the glazed pork buns were good. The pork dumplings were tasty, although came with sweet and sour sauce (odd?). For the four of us, it was about $30. The hostess and cashier were very nice and attentive. The cooks were all old chinese men which was a plus. It looked pretty legit.

I will definitely come back when I'm in Vegas and craving dim sum. Food was good, prices were good, service was excellent! The place is pretty small and there aren't a ton of carts. I wasn't expecting much since its Vegas and there aren't as many chinese people here than in Cali. Since I came with no expectations, it was nice to leave full and satisfied. Tip: Go with another Chinese speaking person so you get exactly what you want. lol.

According to the locals in Vegas that we know, this is the best dim sum in town, and I'd say it's pretty decent. The roast pork (which I'd never had before), shrimp dumplings, and the green vegetable sides were my favorite dishes, and everything was at least decent. While we did not have a problem getting a seat at 11:30AM on a Saturday, our local friend told us that long waits are not unusual here so be prepared.
The service is typical of dim sum places (kinda rushed), but generally acceptable. Prices were in line with dim sum in Los Angeles (i.e. less than the overpriced Strip restaurants). Overall, worth the drive to Gold Coast if you're in town and hankering for dim sum. And, still plenty of free parking...

I visit Vegas for trade shows a lot and always wanted to have authentic dim sum. As far as I know, this is the only Chinese restaurant that serves dim sum and its authentic Cantonese style. There're tons of Chinese restaurants along Spring Mountain Road but the food is mediocre at best. But not Ping Pang Pong. This place serves a good selections of dim sum. Recently relocated next door inside the Gold Coast casino, the restaurant underwent some remodeling and the decor looks inviting. Service was expedient but someone unfamiliar with the Chinese culture might find it annoying as servers keep rolling their dim sum carts repeatedly and ask you to order. Overall, this is definitely a gem in Vegas.

Ping Pang Pong = Dim Sum FUN!!!  

So we've been talking about going to get Dim Sum for probably over a year now, honestly!  We finally got around to it this weekend and I can't believe what I've been missing!  Turns out it's like a backwards buffet, except the food is way fresh and instead of going to get it yourself, there are these lovely ladies that bring around an assortment of tasty Chinese treats on carts. The food is hot, fresh and oh soooo savory!  My favorite was the devilishly, delicious fried crab claw and the seaweed salad was scrumptious on the side.  Make sure to ask for some of the chili sauce for dipping those claws though, and it goes well with pretty much everything else too ;) I'm Very much looking forward to a return visit to try some new and exciting culinary delights.

Black bean chicken - Sucked
Shrimp fried rice - Salty
Sesame Shrimp Rolls - Excellent

We tried this place because they advertised on their billboards how their restaurant won all these awards and they were right across the street from our hotel (the palms). The food is definitely authentic tasting, but it was very salty for my liking.

The black bean chicken was recommended by the manager waiting on us, and it was a bad a call. Sounded good, but it turned out not to be so great. Nonetheless when we ate all three items together the food didn't taste so bad.

Still, its definitely not AWARD winning like they paint themselves to be. I wouldn't mind eating here again: as long as I order something different.

I think our biggest mistake was ordering the fried rice. If we had white rice instead, and ordered two other meat dishes other than the black bean chicken it would have been fine.

Maybe i'll do that next time.

This restaurant definitely has potential, we just made poor choices in ordering our food.

Our fault. Service was good. A-Ok.

Had friends staying at the Gold Coast, we ate at the restaurant, great service, great food.  I'm not much on Asian cuisine, but this was great, lots of food and even my friends commented how great it was, and they found their new favorite Chinese restaurant in Vegas..  The waiter was very informative and helpful, took the time to explain things on the menu we didn't know about or understand.

Ping Pang Pong is located in the Gold Coast Casino, which is on West Flamingo next to the Rio and across from the Palms.
This Chinese restaurant was excellent and reminded of the Chinese restaurants back home in Hawaii. Excellent tasting food with good portions. We shared between 5 people 5 dishes and we were all stuffed after we were done. The Chinese tea was too light in flavor for me, but the 2nd pot brought out tasted better.
We met family from Hawaii for dinner. Everyone loved the food. Well done! My husband is hard to please, local Hawaiian boy, he is so picky and he can't wait to go back. SO the food is GOOD!
 And the service was well done as well. The service team worked together as a team to take care of us.

The general consensus on yelp is that PPP has very good to great Chinese food and bad service. I can say that is right on. We ordered several items and found the portions to be hearty and flavorful. I would recommend to anyone on food alone. This is not a place you order orange chicken and other Panda Express fare. 
Now the bad, total disorganized mess trying to get seated. While waiting in the designated spot multiple people were seated before us just because they were a) clueless and just walked up to the pay register b) jerks for skipping line or c) in the know and didn't feel like waiting in line like a rube
We ordered a dish off the chefs special menu which was mushrooms, bamboo and sausage. When it arrived there was no sausage. When we flagged down the waitress after some confusion she devised the story that the translation of sausage was asparagus. So she did not say sorry and come back with the sausage she instead insults our meager intelligence. I'd like to point out that one side of menu is written in Chinese characters then in English on other side. So even if there was some regional dialect in which the word sausage somehow meant asparagus, it feels ludicrous to even type that, then why would the English translation say "sausage"? The explanation itself made no sense not to mention this type of confusion would happen 12x a night if that were the case. What kind of maniac would just automatically assume sausage actually meant asparagus? The mere man hours involved in handling all the complaints would require a quick menu revision. ANYWAY, since it was so tasty we overlooked it but I'm fairly sure not everyone would just be cool with such a dumb explanation, non apology.
Ping Pang Pong is like the good looking person who can get away with being a jerk because they are so attractive. I'll probably go back but as soon as the food quality slips some this place will be a ghost town much like the aging beauty who treated people like servants her whole life

I have been to Ping Pang Pong for Dim Sum and it was ok.  I do not remember it being great as I love dim sum and will drive almost an hour to China Town in Los Angeles to have it.  And I have never gone out of my way to drive a few minutes to have dim sum at Ping Pang Pong.  Tonight my husband and I had dinner at Ping Pang Pong.  It was awful.  Not bad awful, terrible awful.  I had the Chilean sea bass which was deep fried in greasy oil.  Seems they deep fried it to avoid the fishiness.  But it did not take away the fishy taste.  My husband had the duck and it was not great.  He was hungry after the duck and we ordered the Gobo Beef dish.  it was so awful we both took a bite and that was it.  Left the entire dish.  We have eaten lots of meals and I have never seen my husband leave a full plate of food.  Service was not great but that never is an issue if the food is good.  The quality of the fish and duck and meat was crap.  The reviews for the dim sum were all pretty good, but having tried the food over dinner, there's no way we will ever go back there.  Still burping from that meal and I think I may be seeing it come back up very soon.

I am not going to waste a lot of time here but I would suggest if you think this food is anything CLOSE to 4 or 5 stars I question your taste buds! 
The salt & pepper pork chops were nothing but fat & bone. The fried rice was a basic white rice with boiled chicken. No seasonings & when I asked for a knife to cut off the fat our waitress ignored me for 5 min while waiting on tables who had already been served "many" food items way before us. No refill on soda until we were ready to leave. Then as we are leaving she decided to stand by our table asking if everything was ok? Having eaten in many 5 star resturants on the west coast & midwest this is one step below panda express at best!
Terrible service & obviously only wants to cater to Asians!
Never again!! Yuck!

Best place for Dim sum. Always has been and my family has been going to ping pang pong for years. Quality and taste of the dim sum is the best in town IMO. I love the recent remodel. And seems like the customer service has gotten better too.

It's good, esp considering since there's really no other place I know of to get good dim sum around the Vegas area.
We ordered the shrimp har gow, the siu mai, some chive thing that is first steamed, then fried on both sides.  BF got his steamed pork buns and ate every last one.  I got some porridge since I had been sick, and it was helped me feel better, love the crispy wontons.
I was pretty stuffed.  Dimsum for two.. about $30, pretty reasonable, or average, depends on how you look at it, and how much you eat.
It was nice to have dimsum in LV, but it was just okay.  Nothing to rave about.  Maybe I'm just jaded by the plethora of dim sum restaurants I live by.

Wow this place moved and the service and food got better. Im a dim sum connoisseur and i am impressed how this place has improved. Service is better especially when Alex is around. Very attentive to all tables. Highly recommend this place again

Well, having just recently having gone to the epic Din Tai Fung chain, I wasn't enamored with PPP. It was probably a little less expensive, but the flavors didn't pop quite as much, the quality shine the same way, and the service wasn't very attentive. 

I had hot tea and they didn't have honey only sweet and low, kinda odd. We ordered some dim sum, a Shrimp noodle dish my guest picked out, and Chilean Sea Bass with some sort of fried glaze around it, which made an already oily fish very greasy. Don't get me wrong, the cuisine wasn't terrible, but I guess I'm just recently spoiled from DTF. 

Sorry, didn't take pictures. It was a business dinner and I felt weird about snapping pics throughout the meal. I'm such a bad, bad, bad Yelper! Nothing noteworthy missed though.

Great dim sum at this place. I wasn't blown away by it, but it didn't disappoint. After waiting an hour for a table I was hoping to be blown away. They didn't have anymore of a couple of my favorite items, but I made up for it trying new things. 

The shrimp balls are amazing! Pork buns were delicious. They also have good noodle dishes. We did not order anything from the regular menu. 

Service was good. Staff was friendly.

I mentioned how long the wait was for a table...This place is packed. It's not a huge place, basically two rooms. Be prepared to wait or get there before they open. Dim sum ends at 3:00PM when they close for their afternoon break. They reopen for regular dinner at 5:00PM. 

Check it out. After all, they are world famous!

Enjoy!

Inside the Golden Coast casino, we came here at 2pm after 15 minuets we got seats.Very good business ,we ordered a lot of dishes I love dim sum it's very yummy.I love this place full of strong Chinese style!

Although the availability of good dim sum in Las Vegas is severely lacking, I may have found a good substitute when I tried Ping Pang Pong this past weekend. Located in the Gold Coast Casino, I never thought I would find something close to decent within a casino. I wouldn't go too much off the fact that the casino boasts this place as one of the top 10 Chinese restaurants in Travel + Leisure magazine, but fresh off a remodel and redesign this past summer, the decor and location are nice enough to attract hotel patrons, and the food is authentic enough to attract locals. 

Dim sum service runs from 10:00 am to 3:00 pm, but the carts start tapering off towards the end. They have all the usual classics such as siu mai, chicken feet, BBQ pork buns, and har gow. Although they started running out of some dishes, we asked the manager if we could order the fried crab claws shrimp ball and she got the chef to fry up a fresh batch, just for us. I was pretty happy with that and the service in general. Prices range based on categories of food (A): $2.18 (B): 3.18 (C): $3.88 (D): $5.88. It was pretty affordable for a place that looks much nicer than Yum Cha on Tropicana. The wait time for a table on a Sunday was roughly 10 minutes.

We have come here consistently every time we come to Vegas and noticed changes but this time it's been the worst. 
This place used to be good but now the quality of the food has gone down from the past and so has the service. 


They stop marking fresh food around 1-1;30p even they close at 3pm and keeps on coming around with old food. 
Portion is smaller on some of the dish. 
Hai giao was the only thing that was good. 

We asked several servers and hostess regarding a dish we wanted and none came back to tell us if they have it or not. 

The manager then come over to tell us they do not have it and that they can't make anymore. 
Yet comes back few min later to give us the dish, lied to us about the availability without checking with the kitchen. He never came back to apologize either. 

I'm very disappointed in this place and not sure if I'd want to return here.

found my new favorite Chinese restaurant. not only the dim sum..but we tried the noodle omg it was so yummy. still have long way to go to try their menus. the price is bit pricey when you only go there for 2 lol.but that's because they have big portion on their plates. next time we''ll come with more people and just order few items and share it. that should be perfect! overall it was a great experienced and the food came out fast.

It's your average Chinese restaurant. The dishes aren't extraordinary as it's the same as anywhere else in Chinatown. (Maybe it's because I'm from San Francisco, and our Chinese food here is BOMB.) The location is just much nicer, since it's located inside a casino. The utensils and the restaurant is really clean.

Food is great.  Definitely must get the black pepper beef medallions.  Service is hit or miss.  Ironically enough, their actual servers, and especially bussers, give great service.  When they are busy or understaffed, and the managers step in to help, it goes down the drain.  They are slow, unattentive, and rude.  Eating by myself at Ping Pang Pong, a male manager waited on me one night.  After finishing my meal, I sat for 27 minutes (yes, I kept track) without receiving the check.  When I went to the front, where he was laughing with an employee, and asked for my check, he just rolled his eyes at me, and did not even apologize for the wait.
