Quality of service does not match with its reputation

My boyfriend and i came here on a Monday. It wasn't a very busy time but apparently they didnt care about customer service. Too bad if you were seated near the cashier, because the food cart will never come to you. Their pad see ew was far less than satisfactory but was priced as an E($7). The seasoning wasnt mixed equally with the noodles. It's 100% not worth coming if you have to lyft here.

Last year I went to Ping Pang Pong with my boss and wasnt that impressed. I remember liking 1 dish and thinking the rest was just ok.

Went back a couple of days ago and had a much better  experience. All the dishes we tried were pretty tasty and service was quick. Standout dish was the BBQ pork. Mmmmm.

The restaurant looks very nice, except that the service is horrible. Front service has NO SMILE. We ordered to go, and they have no condiments for take out food. Very reluctant to attend their customers. In China, service is much better. What us wrong with the Chinese in the US? We will never ever come back here

Dim sum in Vegas?  I have to say this place is a blast.  If you like noisy and crowded restaurants where employees wheel around carts of dim sum then this place is for you.
I liked it.  I had the fried shrimp, pan friend dumplings, shrimp balls, and another dumpling that I cannot name, only point to on the cart.  The food was tasty and the service prompt.

Finally got a chance to visit after Ping Pang Pong's move within Gold Coast. I always thought the food here was good, but my big complaints about the old location were the terrible service and the invasive cigarette smoke that used to get drawn into the old restaurant. The new location of the restaurant seems to have mitigated both problems, as the tables are now set back much further from the casino floor and the better "flow" of the floor layout means that the servers can move around more easily and thus more quickly.

I also thought the servers were friendlier than before, but tough to draw a conclusion from just one visit. I'll update my review after some more visits and if the service remains improved, I think this could be a 5*.

As I mentioned, I always thought the food here was top notch and that hasn't changed. I did try one new dish, the jellyfish and roast duck with asparagus stir-fry in xo sauce, and that was killer. Old staples like the dragon well shrimp, lamb stew hotpot, and XO calamari with lotus root are exactly the same as I remember.

IMO Ping Pang Pong also is the best dim sum place currently open in Vegas.

*The strong casino scent probably ruined my appetite.* it is just average chinese food, anyone could cook their quality. I wouldn't visit here again, considered it requires a little drive from the strip. Dim Sum was okay.. I grew up in Hong Kong, and I know the ones they served are mostly microwaved.

I thought the food was delicious. The dim sums were some of the best I've ever had. But make sure to go on the days they have the carts. You get more options that way. I think the carts are on the weekends. Make sure you try the roasted crispy chicken in the scallion soy sauce. So simple, and so good. 
Now that we moved to the west coast & I've had the chance to try dimsum in many more restaurants, I now realize they have one of the best dimsum I've tried. Everything I have tried here has great texture & all flavorful. The exterior of all the dimsum I have tried here are all delicate & thin as I prefer. Soft & chewy in the inside too. Other dimsum I have tried has been tough & chewy. And really missing the flavor ping pang & another favorite I have in Vegas has. Las Vegas really knows how to do dimsum. 

As for service, they can get busy sometimes. But we usually have great service.

They have a nice variety of dim sum however in my opinion it's not the best place for dim sum in Vegas.  The prices seem a little more reasonable than some of the restaurants on the strip that serve dim sum. The service was good and the carts are constantly circulating so there's no shortage of food when you're ready to order more. I will try the dinner menu next time I'm at the Gold Coast but I will go elsewhere for dim sum.

I've had the chance to be in this side of town more and wanted to check out the restaurants. One of my coworkers recommended this place and I thank her all of the time for showing me Ping Pang Pong. The service was fast and the portions are great for groups. It is fairly priced and I'm glad I had people with me that knew what to order because Chinese food isn't my expertise. I got a Thai style fried rice and I loved it. The plum wine was also fantastic. Need to come back.

The best dim sum ever in LV that we ever tasted.  If you stay at the strip like we did, you have to drive a bit.  It's close to the china town.  
ANyway, a friend of mine said that this place is good.  So, we gave it a try.  We noticed their giant billboards all over the place. 
Anyway, we got there. Although, it wasn't full house, they were quite busy.  We waited for a few minutes after we got our tables to be approached by the ladies with the dim sum carts.  We ordered quite a lot. As 2 giant piggies, we finished everything.  :)
The conclusion is good food, price is not bad. The only thing that keeps me from giving 5 stars is the service.  There was totally none.  We'll probably come back here just to grab quick dim sum.
Overpriced and miniocre. I don't think I'll come back again.  There's just way more dim sum restaurants id pick over this one.
Nothing special - this place is located in the corner of a smoky casino. The food was average - nothing really stood out to me as being particularly memorable.

I met a friend from Canada for dinner at Ping Pang Pong tonight.  My only other dining experience here was with the same friend about 4 years ago.

We ordered three dishes to share:  The Singapore rice noodles were excellent.  There was a fair number of shrimp and some small slices of pork along with onions.  The curry flavor was good.  For my taste, I could have used a bit more.  We got an order of wrinkled green beans.  I don't think they were seared as much as they should have been to make them wrinkled.  They were crisp.  Their flavor was very good.  Finally, we got the half roasted Cantonese duck.  The flavor of the duck was a winner, too!  I'm not a big fan of duck when it's on the bone, but this was cooked well.  

Service was good.  My iced tea refilled often without asking.  We did have to ask a server to bring us some clean plates so we could get rid of some of the duck bones.  

The one drawback of Ping Pang Pong was the loudness of the place for the first 1/3 of the hour and a half we were there.  It was so noisy from people talking loudly and the kitchen staff, filling orders for take out and yelling the orders to each other.

I do like the place and I will be back if only for the Singapore noodles.  That was my highlight of the meal!

PS:  I love the name.  I can't help think of Puccini and Turandot!  Addio amore, addio razza....

i went here w/ my family and the food was delicious. surprisingly coz most chinese places are dirty but this one was actually good. they have this really cool kitchen where you see the chefs cooking your food. it's great for a casino restaurant...you gotta try it. it tastes fresh and autentic.

Kristy is this amazing manager who treats us every time like VIPS!!!!! and Yannie Wang was just the best waitress ever.
The 2 of them made our dinner so enjoyable.
The food was absolutely delicious!!!!

Besides the name being cute and funny there wasn't much else. 
There was like only one waitress that was working the table and the carts coming aroubd were pretty slow. 
Dim sum variety were pretty typical and looked liked it was frozen, defrosted and put in the steamer for display. 
The tastes of the dishes were mediocre. The unexpected delicious treat was the coconut bread which was sweet and filled with coconut gooeyness. 
Other than that, I have had better dim sum in la that were bigger in size and fresher in taste.

4 dim sum stars for LV standards (I mean, this is NOT Hong Kong or LA's SGV.)

Here's some of the dishes I remember: 
1. Marinated chicken feet
2. Fried taro balls
3. Sticky rice in banana leaves 
4. Sweet tofu flower soup (huge!) 
5. Sticky rice cake with matcha filling 
6. Almond covered shrimp 
7. Sesame covered shrimp
8. Beef chung fun 

Haha...the Ping Pang Pong name is soooo wrong. When actually looking at the Chinese characters, it literally means golden yen treasure.

Newly remodeled lobby...menu is still wonderful! Ginger mushroom chicken claypot, ox tail, salt and pepper pork chops. Again,  if you don't know or ENJOY authentic C H I N E S E food as in mainland China... don't come here b/c you will be disappointed. Broccoli beef, orange chicken, egg rolls no!  not here go to Panda for that. Otherwise, sit back and enjoy the trip without the airfair.

Freshest dim sum in Vegas.  Best quality, best taste, best texture, and best flavors.  Nothing beats Ping Pang Pong so far in my dim sum book.  Except the egg custard buns from Orchids Garden.  

This place is by far my favorite place to eat dim sum.

Having a family member who gambles through the night til the sunrise means comps and free food. We frequent here because other dining place in Gold Coast Hotel sucks so bad and Ping Pang Pong is the only decent place besides Noodle Exchange (their beef combination noodle is yummers!  but that's besides the point). 

SERVICE
Service is terrible. Servers here are slower than a turtle. However, I do want to talk about their cleaning guys (two brothers). They clean dirty dishes and wipe tables like there's no tomorrow. Holy moly. They could easily win 1st place at table cleaning contest if there's such thing. It's worth watching them while your servers takes her sweet time getting your orders.

FOOD
Some of my favorites that I get every time:

Sea Bass Hot Pot ($19.95)- it's one of their secret menu. Mainly tofu and fried sea bass with lots of garlic. Little bit pricey but worth it. Yum yum.

Walnut Prawns ($13.95)- fried shrimp with sesame mayonnaise and honey-glazed walnuts. It's the ultimate fatty dish with lots of cholesterol but it's so dang good. 

Tea Smoked Duck ($16.95)- roasted duck in a wrap with boison sauce on the side. I can eat this everyday!

Chicken with Black Bean Sauce ($9.95)- goes well with a bowl of white rice 

Shanghai Noodles ($7.95)- stir-fried Napa cabbage, mushrooms, spinach and pork

Singapore Rice Noodles ($9.95)- noodles with light curry flavor. 

Garlic Bok Choy- Always ask for extra garlic!

Last but most definitely not least, thier mango pudding. Comes with creamer on the side. They make fresh mango pudding here and it is the most flavorful and refreshing dessert. My family of 3 always order about 10 of these LOL 

*dim sum here is alright. Much rather go to other places. 

CONCLUSION
Their service sucks but delicious food makes up for it.

I have discovered P3 since 2013.  I visit evey 4th of July week up to 2016.  Still it is the best dimsum place!  

I had dim sum very much every where. By far this place was the best.  Although don't expect the best service.  It seems like most Chinese restaurant service is not that great.  I would visit again but I will only tip them based on service!

This  restaurant is Amazing I have had Chinese  food many times but this one is totally on another level. service was  amazing . The food was unbelievable.  I recommend this  to all of the Chinese  food lovers. I wish I could give them 100 more stars ( I mean it ) 
Thank you Rose  for taking me to Ping Pang Pong.

Ping Pang Pong is definitely one of my top choices for dim sum here in Vegas.  

First, the restaurant is small so it doesn't take too terribly long for the carts to circulate and deliver piping hot dim sum foods to you!  I am not a fan of luke warm dim sum.  This is often a problem when a place isn't busy and things circulate for too long or when a place is too big and the carts have travel vast distances from kitchen to patron.  

They offer all of my faves like chinese broccoli with oyster sauce, baked char shiu bau (sp?), shrimp and chive nuggets, crab balls, chow fun, shiu mai (sp?).  OK, OK I admit I have absolutely no idea how to name or spell most of the hot tiny treasures but I love to eat them!  One complaint here at ping pang pong, is that they serve the oyster sauce on the side of the chinese broccoli....I must prefer a heart drizzle evenly over the top.  

They are friendlier than most but still the service is abrupt, semi-angry, and without any normal pleasantries.  This is to be expected from most Chinese establishments, especially dim sum.  But the attitude adds to the experience if you ask me!  

If it is your first crack at dim sum, this may be the best place to try it.  The ladies pushing the carts even explained what was in some of the items!  Revolutionary.  

Dim sum at ping pang pong is better than most here in town but not the best ever, but definitely worth a try!!!

Went here for dim sum today based on recommendations from friends. I wasn't very impressed. It was good but it was nothing special and I am glad I didn't go when it was crowded.

Food: The food was good but it was nothing special. The only thing I thought was really good was the steamed bbq pork buns which were really moist. Only thing was that they stuck to the paper and fell apart a bit. There was a decent selection of dim sum but not that many. The shimp dumplings and shrimp rice rolls were not very flavorful.

Service: Not the best dim sum service I have had. The carts took a while to come by and some carts came by more times than others. I had to grab the servers' attention to get drink order refills.

Price. A lot pricier than the other dim sum places I have been. I paid $45 for food that would usually cost 26 to 35 elsewhere. 

Overall, the dim sum was okay but I don't think I want to go back (there are other places to go).
I think they should take of soft turttle shells. I am really ANGRY!!!!, with that. It is just wrong. They are really almost in endangered. I think the food is great but just take it of :[

Came here because I was told this is one of the good dim sum places in Vegas.  I'll be honest, I had better.  The wait time to get dim sum such as the chicken feet, tripe, spare ribs, etc took about :30mins since we were seated.  The tripe and spare ribs were bland.  Only good thing was the fried rice and noodles.

I really don't know if the name of this restaurant is catchy or annoying???  I'll let you decide that.  If you have been to Gold Coast in the past couple years, you'll find that the casino has been trying to attract more and more Chinese tourists.  With Ping Pang Pong, they are able to offer the locals as well as the visitors a taste of the mother land.  That means this place serves authentic Chinese food.  We thought the amount of food for the price paid was not equal; however, even to us Asians the food was quite tasty.

My family and I LOVE coming here. Hands down, the best dim sum in all of Vegas.

Ping Pang Pong is located inside the Gold Coast Casino. The restaurant is extremely big and can accommodate large parties pretty easily. Depending on the day and time, the line can get pretty long. My family and I usually come here on the weekdays to avoid the long lines.

Food is bomb. If only I knew the names, or even how to spell the names of the dishes we order. Most of the time we just point to what we want, if we don't know what they are technically called. Here are a few that I remember and that I would recommend: Siu Mai, Har Gow, Shrimp Ball w/ Sugar Cane, Chive Dumpling, BBQ Steamed Bun, Coconut Bun, and Egg Tarts! 

The reason why I'm only giving this place 4 stars instead of 5 is because it's pretty pricy compared to other dim sum places.. and the service is sometimes bad.

I have been harboring some nasty suspicions for some time, and last night, I think my worst fears were confirmed. I am just a regular, non-ethnic white girl. I cannot eat the food that they actually eat in Japan and China. When I am served chicken at a restaurant that is cold (on purpose), yellow, still has the skin on, and has chopped up bones in it, I don't even want to take a bite.Fried pieces of pork that still have the fat on them do not appeal to me. A soup that is served with a huge bone in it with tiny scraps of meat and fat clinging to it does not look appetizing. In the spirit of adventure, I ate a few bites of everything, and it wasn't disgusting or anything, just meh.

In fairness, Ping Pang Pong also has some of the traditional American-y dishes you can get at your local Chinese takeout, but we were looking to branch out and try some new things. I'm not upset with the restaurant - I'm sure this is excellent preparation of Princess Chicken or Salt & Pepper Porkchops - they just aren't for me.

We also tried the singapore noodles, which were kinda like your standard Lo Mein, and some fried rice, which I thought was really good. Our final order was the wrinkled green beans, and they were also good. Overall, we mostly stuck to the noodles and the rice. 

Our 6 dishes and 2 drinks ran about $80, so it's higher than your average takeout place, but still reasonable. We had enough food to easily feed 4 people.

The atmosphere inside is nice - kind of like any casino restaurant between casual and fine dining. The drawback there is that it's open to the extremely smoky Gold Coast casino floor.

Everything I've eaten there has been absolutely wonderful! When my family comes to visit we made sure to try to hit this place up every single time. The food will not disappoint you but the service though they are attentive they can be quite rude and I mean quite rude!

3.5 STARS

Yay! It's hella Chinesey up in here!

Normally you can judge how good an Asian restaurant is by the amount of native diners. Vegas is no exception.

Ping Pang Pong came as a recommendation from my friend who lives in Vegas but he did warn me it's not nearly as good as the dim sum in SF.. 

On Sunday, 9.11.11, my friends and I came to PPP at 1 PM. It was about a 15 minute wait for a party of 7. The FIRST thing I noticed was the overwhelming amount of Mandarin and Cantonese speaking patrons; seemed promising.

FOOD
Ladies push around dim sum carts and call out the dishes in Cantonese. They are more than happy to show you what's inside the steamers if you don't understand Cantonese.

We ordered the following (some in doubles):
*Hai Gow (Steamed Shrimp Dumplings)
*Siu Mai (Steamed Pork Dumplings)
*Hai and Char Siu Cheung Fun (Steamed Shrimp and BBQ Pork Noodle Rolls)
*Fung Zhao (Steamed Chicken Feet)
*Ngau Yuk Mai (Steamed Beef Balls)
*Jiaozi (Potstickers)
*Deep Fried Shrimp Balls
*Paai Gwaat (Steamed Spare Ribs)
*Ngau Toa (Steamed Tripe)
*Fu Pei Guen (Steamed Tofu Skin Roll)
*Lo Mai Gai (Steamed Glutinous Rice w/ Chicken in Lotus Leaf Wrap)
*Jin Deui (Fried Sesame Balls)
*Char Siu Chow Fan (BBQ Pork Fried Rice)

The only standout dishes was the steamed tripe which was melt-in-your-mouth soft and the fried rice which was al-dente which bits of rich fatty pieces of pork (albeit a bit greasy).  The rest of the dishes were mediocre; they either lacked quality ingredients, were tiny (dumplings) compared to the norm and/or on the dry side. But when you're starving and there's a lack of good dim sum options, it sufficed just fine.

S E R V I C E
Perhaps, I'm so use to rude service at Asian restaurants that I didn't find the service at PPP even the slight bit rude. Our waiter brought things quickly when we asked for it and refilled our waters promptly. This in itself is already a rarity in most Chinese restaurants.
 
A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
With a name like Ping Pang Pong, it's no wonder that it excudes the typical stereotypical dcor of Chinese village roof shingles, red paper lanterns and waitstaff in mandarin collared outfits. Most importantly, It was CLEAN!

With a plethora of dim sum restaurants in San Francisco, PPP would probably rank a 2.5-3 STARS in SF. However, considering Vegas has a scant amount of decent Asian restaurants and we left stuffed for only $15/person (including tip) they do deserve a better than average rating.

Some of the best Dim Sum in Las Vegas.  They have a better than average selection.  It's fresh and tastes good. The ambiance is a little off - you have to walk through an especially smoky casino to get there, but it's worth it.  It's also kind of loud when it is busy.  Service is not bad, but what appeals to me is that usually I can get in and out within 30 minutes.

My mom took me here so I can try this place out. She said they have more dim sum selections and what not. 

I did not like the place at all. Seating sucked (if you're right at the entrance)

Not a lot of dim sum selection at all either. All the carts that came around were the same thing that passed us earlier. So a lot of the food I normally eat, they don't have. 

Their portion is smaller as well. As in, most places give you 3 egg tarts and this place gives you 2. Same for other dishes like the rice wrapped with leaves. 

Compared to DJ Dim Sum in Rio, this place has a major thumbs down in food and in service for sure. Don't think I'll ever come back.

Coming from 626 in LA where dim sum places are plentiful, this dim sum place is pretty bomb except for the price. They offer all the typical dim sum dishes, and they have some special ones like the beef brisket. 

Pro tip: come a little before 10 to avoid the line! If you come after 11, be prepared to wait at least an hour on the weekend!

The food here is delicious better then a lot of the ones in LA love this place their deep fried salted fish is amazing and the fried tofu food here is made with love! luv this place!!!!!  hands down the best chinese food place in lv!!! Reservations. Needed!!!

I'm only giving this place such a high rating is because of the food, which was good, but the service absolutely sucked. Waited in line for about 10 mins before anyone acknowledged we were in line. Another 10 mins before our order was taken. When it did come, it came incomplete and the last dish came out over 10 mins after our first dish came out. The manageress then tried to bullshit me by saying that the particular item takes longer to cook because they needed to fry it first. She shut up when I called her out on it as I have owned a Chinese restaurant before and knew what goes into making sweet and sour pork. I would've rather she just say I'm sorry we fucked up, it's coming right up. Never try and make lame excuses to the customer.  I guess she feels what happens in Ping Pang Pong, stays in Ping Pang Pong.

It's very decent.  I wanted to check out dim sum in Las Vegas.  We came on a Saturday morning, and at the stroke of 10, when they open, a number of tables were already filled.  They have the standard dishes, including two types of jook.  We left probably an hour or so later, and the same carts had rotated around several times.  There were a couple of dishes brought around on trays.  The variety isn't very large, but I liked it better than Five Star Seafood (fka New Capital) in Monterey Park.

It's a good dim sum fix when in Vegas.

Hands down the best dim sum in LV.  We used to go to what is now Orchid's Garden when it was still named Chau's then moved on to Chang's, and dabbled with Cathay House.  All of these restaurants would hover around 3 stars and dipped as low as being inedible depending on change of chefs and perhaps even ownership.  Then along came the idea of trying Ping Pang Pong inside the Gold Coast casino.

The litmus test for dim sum for me are the cheong fun, the har gow, the oven baked char siu bao, chicken feet, and anything with shrimp.  While the sauce of the cheong fun was very light, the noodles were soft and the shrimp were fresh. The har gow skin was soft and the shrimp again fresh.  The char siu bao was the right combination of sweet and salty.  Chicken feet were not too soft and not too hard.  Did I mention the shrimp were fresh?!

Yes, it's considerably pricier than all the other dim sum restaurants I mentioned but it's worth it.  And yes, it's also frigid cold like another reviewer said because that's how casinos keep you awake but it's nothing hot tea and a sweater can't fix.  And yes, it can get very crowded since it's actually a fairly small dining room for a dim sum restaurant, not to mention a dim sum restaurant in a casino known for its Asian clientel, but go before 11:30 am and you'll be fine since most are either at the gambling tables or are sleeping in from being at the gambling tables all night.

Whoa, second day in a row that I picked a place with a huge crowd and a wait.

I think I could've legitimately done without the wait. They have a sign pointing to a waiting area just outside of the restaurant, but they didn't seem to have a dedicated host. I stood there for at least 5 minutes before they even so much as said hi to the party in front of us, and another 5 before they seated us. It was very busy, but at least I should've been welcomed, and I'm pretty sure there were at least a couple of open tables.

By the way, try to park at the side of Gold Coast farthest from the Rio if you want to have a shorter walk, which is healthier than it sounds due to less secondhand smoke exposure.

Anyway, as with any good dim sum place, we were able to dive right in since the carts made their rounds quickly. My friend started off the picks with a har gow (4 pieces), a shu mai (4), and a rather large and unfamiliar bowl of some sort of tripe with ginger and daikon. I later got us a plate of shrimp stuffed eggplant pieces (3), some deep fried shrimp balls with sugar cane (2) and some nice compact egg tarts (2). The last item was the chicken feet that my friend was pining for the whole time.

Everything was definitely on the high end of good. All the savory items had sufficient flavor and non-mushiness, and the egg tarts were very flaky and were still noticeably warm at the end of the meal even though I'd ordered them at the start. I didn't fall in love with any one dish, but the quality was solid overall. Prices are probably a bit more than you'd expect since it's a casino restaurant and there's not all that many dim sum shops here. It was most likely $5.88 each for the tripe bowl and chicken feet, per my friend, and we had one $2.18 order, four $2.88 items, and one $3.88 dish. Couldn't tell you which is which since I'm not that much of a dim sum connoisseur, sorry! 

Overall, I wasn't blown away by any single item, but it was solid dim sum and I definitely prefer this to East Ocean, which has seemed a little lacking for me the past couple of trips for some reason. I also definitely appreciated that we got a tangerine and candy here instead of a fortune cookie (looking at you, East Ocean). I have not been to KJ yet, so stay tuned in case I decide to hit them up.

dim sum yay!   Haven't had anything from the regular menu here but the dim sum lunch was just like back home in the bay area!  $30 for 2 people, and we were stuffed, the carts just kept on coming! **it gets a little crowded and it's in the middle of the casino, but if it's cheap and the food is good...I'm all for it and besides...it's Vegas baby!!

Customer service was blah. But food was good. Too bad the servers don't really know much about what they are serving. I enjoyed the food though. It does get very busy & the wait can be long. My best advice is too call ahead & see if there is a wait. Cool thing about this place is they do have dim sum to go!!!!!

Went on a Monday morning right at opening time with a party of 8, none of us Chinese nor fluent in figuring out what things are on the carts. I've had dim sum in San Francisco and Toronto; this visit, this day, PPP was almost on par. Almost everything was delicious. We had several different dumplings, some buns and several selections from the menu as well. One standout (again, I apologize for not knowing names) was a shrimp dumpling that had a creamy, slightly sweet filling that almost "burst" in the mouth, and was served with candied walnuts. Oh. My. That was so good. Other dishes featuring pork, beef and chicken were fantastic.

Total bill including tax and tip for 8 people and a ton of dim sum and 5-6 menu dishes: $200. An absolute steal. If I could go 4.5 stars, I'd do so. Ping Pang Pong is a winner.

The best dim sum we have had in Las Vegas. The wait was definitely worth it. If you are a dim sum lover like me, this is the place to go. It was authentic Asian dim sum. My favorite were the BBQ pork buns. There were lots of different things to try and wasn't able to try it all. Strange that it was located in an older hotel, but the food tasted great!

OK, I'm going to give up one of my favorite haunts in Vegas.  I was hesitant to tell people about this place.  LOVE their dim sum, it's all I've ever had there so I can not comment on their Chinese Food.  I can tell you though that 98% of their customers are Asian and so that is a huge indicator of the level of authenticity.  In the past we had trouble communicating with the staff because they usually speak in their own language, this last time though it seems they have hired more English speaking staff and it was considerably easier to order.

Everyone is smiley and happy, the worst part is getting seated.  There is ALWAYS  a wait, I don't care what time or day you go, but once you get seated being it's dim sum there is no wait for food and it just keeps rolling past you for your pleasure.  I love everything we have ever had there and they are reasonable with their cost.

The worst part of this place is that it is located in the Gold Coast and you have to wade through the heavily smoked environment to get to the restaurant, but even going through that is worth it for this place.

The only dim sum I've had in Vegas, but it's done well at Ping Pang Pong! Okay yes, the name is pretty ridiculous and stereotypical to Chinese people, but don't let that turn you off! This place is pretty legit.

A lot of reviewers mention that the wait is pretty crazy, but I've came here on weekdays only and never had to wait for a table, so maybe it's only crazy on weekends?

All the dishes we've had were good, but we've only came here for dim sum, so I'm not sure (but curious) how their other food is.

Service is decent, which I'm used to at Chinese restaurants, so it's good enough for me!

Kind of shocked that this place was noted as the 'Best Chinese Restaurant of 2011'. Is nothing good in Chinatown then? Haha.

My family visits often. We love the afternoon dim sum. For those of you who are new to dim sum, it is a style of Cantonese cuisine prepared as small bite-sized portions of food & served in steamer baskets or small plates. It's nice to have a wide variety of selection & be able to eat the moment you are seated. Everything is good here: the tea, the foods, the desserts. I would have given Ping Pang Pong 5 stars but their customer service is below average but that can be contributed to the language barrier as I do not speak Mandarin or Cantonese. I would still recommend this place for the food & experience! Order the shrimp balls, it's delish!

This place has hands down the best pork buns in the universe. If you had a spaceship named the Millenium Falcon, you still could not travel far enough in this universe to find better pork buns. I could have eaten 100 of them. Everything else was very good too. I had never tried that rice porridge stuff before, but my girl got some from the dim sum cart and that stuff is way better than it looks lol. Everything we got was really very good, but the pork buns just blew me away. Every time I go to Vegas for the rest of my life, I will eat at this restaurant and probably pig out on the pork buns in the most disgustingly gluttonous way possible lol. I can't stop thinking about them. sooooo good. Ambiance is very nice too, and the service was very friendly and attentive.
If you like M S G this is the spot for you! A lot  ! Please learn how to cook properly without it....

Despite the ridiculously belittling name (ching chang chong!), this place serves some great, authentic dim sum.  I've been to other places in town (Chang's, Orchid Garden, Cathay House) and this place beats them all! I would even compare it to some of the great dim sum places they have in Chinatown in San Francisco or Los Angeles. The classical dim sum dishes (pork buns, egg tarts, shui mei) all deliver, plus they have some other unique concoctions as well.

The ambiance is great too.  I love sitting in a crowded little dim sum place, with the chatter of happy families eating together, surrounded by beautiful paintings and really great lighting!  They also have an open kitchen too which is pretty neat!

If you're looking for some good dim sum in Las Vegas, then this is the place to go :)

The BBQ pork buns were decent. The Thousand Year Old Egg and shredded pork porridge wasn't bad. Everything else we tried was a miss.

Food-wise, this place is no better or no worse than say, Chang, Orchid Garden, Cathay House...etc. (Actually, Cathay House can be much better on the right day with the right server but that is another review for another day.)

Limited Dim-sum selection and the actual square-footage is quite small.

Not too shabby for a Casino Dim-sum restaurant.

UPDATE:

Did they change their dim sum chef?  These past three times (May, June, and December) we were here, we can really taste the difference.  Not only is the food cold, it is bland and soggy.  

I am going to agree to a previous review, they are terrible when it comes to the line.  They really need a better system. 

Also, their price appears reasonable, but they switched up their dishes to a higher status.  HARDLY anything is an "A Dish."  

This is NO longer my favorite dim sum place in Vegas.

Didn't like this place at all! Kept seeing the TV ad about this place in the station casinos and decide to give it a try! Spring rolls and shrimp and BBQ short ribs! Didn't enjoy none of it and it showed so much that the manager came over and ask if there was something else i would like to try! I refused and thanked her for offering. After a couple of bites i had staff pack up order. I ended up giving left overs to homeless people on the street! I wonder if they were happy?

SOOOO DELISH! I know, I am white so I am obviously not a Dim Sum afficianado however, my aunt (who is Chinese) is and this is where she takes us for dim sum in Vegas. Thank goodness because sometimes it is hard to understand the servers and vice versa. It has to be good if Chinese people eat there in my humble opinion! And there is almost always a line. The food is AMAZING, very fresh and plenty of it, in fact, you will probably overeat. My favorite are the Cha Siu Baos (there are 2 similar versions, one in a sweet white bun and the other in a darker, flakier, triangle shaped bun with sesame seeds) Both are outta this world! Highly reccomend!

Went to Ping Pang Pong for lunch and had dim sum.  The food tasted fine, but the selection was not that great.  It is a small place, so the carts come around ofter.  The prices seemed pretty good.  Seems a bit cheap to charge for tea, but at least they have loose leaf tea.  Places that use tea bags and claim to be Chinese restaurants piss me off.  :)

Shrimp ball,shrimp buns,fried shrimp,steamed shrimp...Shrimp Buffet n Noodles!!haha A whole bunch of small dishes with a BIG price tag!Its VEGAS and if yor craving the far east jump in the cab and say "olympic garden!"oh youre Hungry??!! i thought u said something else!haha Go to panda express and use the rest of yo loot on some designer socks.

Large variety of food and great service. I ordered the pineapple shrimp fried rice and I was pleased. The portion  sizes are massive. My husband and I decided, after we ordered of course, that we should have shared a meal! You'll definitely get your money's worth. On the way in, I heard someone say, "I hope you're hungry" to another person who was in line. Now I know what he meant by that. We went during the lunch rush and the line was very long, but we wweee seated pretty quickly considering  how long the line was. 

The appetizers and single portion items are carted around to each table. My husband wasn't a fan of one of the items, and I'm not even sure what it was. It was some type of meat wrapped in cabbage. We also had sweet bread. If we had more time here, I would definitely visit again, especially now that I know what to expect, and the flow of things.

It was my first time eating here and the food was absolutely delicious!! My girlfriend and I ordered the chicken fried rice, fried calamari, Mongolian beef, and wanton soup. The chicken fried rice had a different flavor and wasn't a bad thing. The Mongolian beef was a bit salty for my taste but it wasn't that over powering. The fried calamari was probably my favorite dish. The wonton soup was just as good. The portions are pretty large so choose wisely. My complaint about this place was service. Servers weren't attentive and it took forever to get refills and what not. But the food did come out pretty quick and they're open til 3am. If you have a late night craving for Chinese food, come to Ping Pang Pong.

Great food, but no service at all. I really like the food. That was good looking and delicious. It was the best dim sum in Los Vegas. However, the waitress always ignore our ask. You should really help yourself in this store.

I couldn't tell if they were short-staffed or the service was just downright bad. I ordered most of the food off the dim sum cart but my boyfriend also wanted to order a dish off the menu. I couldn't tell whose job was what due my first time being there. I saw the hostess walking around me more than a waitress. We were ignored for the duration of our time there. Later, we paid and I tried to give the girl at the front desk (where the cash registers were) and she literally didn't want to help me. Few seconds passed and she asked "oh did you want to pay?" geez..... My change was $6.03 and she didn't even bother to give me the 3 cents back. It's the principle. Just horrible service overall. Food was so-so. Warning: don't be surprised if you receive little to no service at all here.
I love Ping Pang Pong. It is the best dim sum in Vegas. Sometimes the service can be a little slow, but the food is delicious and the prices are so reasonable.

Ping Pang Pong is definitely one of the better places for dim sum in Vegas. They open at 10 and there's a line before it even opens which I was in since I was a bit early. With 10 of us we were seated right after it opened.

We were at the table where all the employees had to open the cabinet to put their personal items so we had to keep moving out of the way. The food carts seemed to have been sparse in our area but we were able to order what we wanted from the server. My favorites were the shrimp churn fun and the gai mei bao. The shrimp
was huge! All of the food was good but I wish we got to have more of a variety like the turnip cake that I love or tripe.  

Ping Pang Pong is definitely a little on the pricey side for dim sum but it is worth it. Even though you do have to walk into a smokey casino you will forget that once you are seated surrounded by loud parties.

Blah. ummmm, yeah NO! Not only do they charge PER beverage (which really ignites my jewish irritation meter), but it's located in the Gold Coast, gh-e-tto!  And the name of the place -ping- just -pang- stresses -pong- me out.

Walk in, smell smoke, see a geriatrics ward of mindless gamblers pawing over their social security check. I felt like strapping a cardboard box to my chest, peruse through asking, "diapers, cigarettes, change for a nickle."

The food was ok, interesting experience needless to say, but they claim to BE THE BEST IN LAS VEGAS! -big bold lettering.  Maybe, it's the only one?!?  Whatev!

Service was crappola, our waitress was oober rude, surfin' the crimson wave apparently!

I won't go back.
Excellent restaurant - the service was great, quick, and polite. The food was delicious and very reasonably priced.. loved

My bf bowls at the Gold Coast once a week and we were looking for something different to eat from the bowling alley snack bar.  We had the Honey Walnut Prawns, Orange Chicken, and Curry Pineapple Seafood Fried Rice.  The prawns and the fried rice were delicious, but the orange chicken was tough and difficult to chew.  The food was pretty expensive (+$50) for what we got, but it may have been different if we had actually eaten at the restaurant and not ordered takeout.  The girls at the register were not very friendly and seemed uninterested and robotic.  I asked a coupe of questions about items on the menu and the girl seemed inconvenienced by having to answer. I was told it would be 30 minutes for my food to be ready, but it took almost an hour!  Overall, some of the food tasted great, but the service was terrible!

The food here is GOOD.
The service here is BAD.

We haven't been to this hidden gem a few times, and all though the food taste great.... their customer service makes me cringe. One time we had came in for dim sum, and the lady kept missing us. They didn't refill water and we felt completely ignored. It was hard to get anyone's attention. We kept having to raise our hands and ask one employee something and they said they would grab the right person and it was a vicious cycle.

Chinese broccoli... $12???  The portions here at ping pang pong are very miniscule.  Typical dim sum really.  However, the service is lackluster.  Not the worst, but far from acceptable.  The multiple times I've come here on occasion I've noticed how most of the employees look like they HATE their job and the customers.  I've had the dishes flung upon the table a few times.  Relax lady XD. There are better places to eat, plus I dislike the line here.  They are pretty terrible at seating, many a time was there open tables and no one being seated.  Sigh... 2 stars because a 3 would be somewhere I'd come back to.

First of all note that portions are family size style not individual portions. So it looks expensive but it is not so expensive unless you are by yourself and have to eat 1 full portion. 
Very quick friendly service. Clean place with nice ambiance. Extensive menu. My spring rolls were very good and I made a mistake with my butter scallops entree  I wasn't thrilled. I saw many other good plates at other tables. :( totally my fault. 

In the end I enjoyed the experience and would go back knowing better what entree I would like to eat.
I have eaten here many times, however I never ordered any entrees. Instead, I always go for the Dim Sum lunch....it is very good, and on par with anything you would find in Chinatown

Food is decent but the service is really really really poor. Forget about getting any take out around 8pm they will take an hour or more just to get the order ready. Even if you call in advance. When you dine in for dim sum its always so busy you can't get even your water refilled. The only reason I gave it a one star is because I like the food but the service is terrible.

Excellent food overall. Not nearly as good as Chinese places in LA. But more than enough to beat the smattering of places in Vegas Chinatown. We came here twice in our weeklong Vegas trip and nearly skipped Chinatown altogether. Dimsum is v good, but dinner dishes are ok, not great.

food: they have most of the items at a dim sum place. with dim sum it's hard to describe. you just know when it's good and when it's not as good. this was the latter. ***2/5

service: they dont go full circles. i was waiting for a cart to come by and it keeps going the other way. as soon we get a cart, we ordered as much as we can. then when i dont need them, it keeps brushing by. the server couldnt be found after some time. ***2/5

value: prices arent too bad, but for what you get, it's not worth it. ok for first timers, but for those have a more experienced dim sum palette, this place is lacking. ***2/5

Delicious selection! Definitely above average and the new location gave it a more modern, clean ambience compared to the previous location. The wait can be extremely discouraging if you are a regular guest and dont know anyone that works here to pull you ahead of line. Expect to wait at least 30 minutes not because of the food but because of the line / seating situation. I have witnessed waiting in line for 30 mins on few occasions and noticed some workers will help their friends get seated faster without waiting which caused most of the public people in line frustrated. Also if you are a casino guest at a certain tier you also get to go in front of line. After groups of friends and casino guests were pulled into the front of line i noticed 3 separate groups of people in line in front of me left because they were upset with the way the line worked which helped me get seated faster. I no longer go inlesa im with group that knows a worker to sneak us in or use my players card for the casino tier. The portions are not as large as other cities and the prices are a bit higher than normal vegas prices but you are paying casino prices so it is on par with the food. Service can be hit and miss but thats a norm in this establishments. Definitely save room for the Pastries!

Very tasty dim sum dishes.  Favorites were the pai gwat fahn (spareribs over rice), nai wong baoh (custard filled bun), dan tat (egg custard dessert), and their gnow yook cheurng fun (beef long noodles).  We also ordered the typical sui mai (pork dumpling), har gaw (shrimp dumpling) and fung jao (chicken feet).  Overall, I really enjoyed the dim sum here and would definitely return the next time we are in the mood for dim sum when visiting the strip in Vegas.  This restaurant is located inside Gold Coast Casino.  

And what's there not to love about the name?  It's definitely memorable.

The good is amazing, the service sucks.  It's really hard to understand the staff.  The dim sum is awesome, we also had chow main noodles, that were good. I especially love the walnut shrimp, it's the best!!! The wonton soup was amazing! Definitely one of the better Chinese places in Vegas.  A must try if you are i town!

This is our family spot for dim sum. It's delicious and they have the most selection of dim sum. The pudding dessert is a must to finish my meal. You have to get there early or there is always a wait.

Food is good but service is awful!!! We went twice and each time it's the same thing, takes forever to get waited on, servers don't check back to see if you need anything and one time they took so long to wait on us that dim sum ended. Don't waste your time go to Changs on Decatur instead! I would not recommend unless you want subpar food at over the top prices.

Fantastic dim sum.  There's a reason why there's always a ferocious line.  Pro tip on Asian food: there should be wait.  You want a place that's so good that even hungry people are willing to stand in line for it.  Ping Pang Pong has got those in spades:  good food & long line.

Needed a quick bite after drinking--these guys are open until 3am!  We ordered the salt and pepper calamari which was great--wished they were a bit more crispy but still satisfied my craving.

Also had the pan fried combination noodles with hefty amounts of meat and shrimp.  Reminded me of the noodles we get in SoCal.

Will definitely return.

I want to give this place 4 stars for the food but 3 star for overall experience. Came here Sunday for dim sum and there was a line. We got sat and we didn't get greeted and our server didn't come check on us. Not good customer service but the food was fine. They didn't have a lot of options and there was only 2 carts going around the whole time. They ran out of items and so we were limited to whatever was left. Next time I would just order take out or go elsewhere for dim sum where it's more options and better service at least.

So 3am comes along, you're hungry, tired, and thirsty after a long day of Vegas adventuring....and you see Ping Pang Pong!!  It was sooooo delicious!  Our waitress was very nice, she even explained items on the menu patiently so our inebriated brains could understand.  Their was a man who always came by to make sure our empty plates were taken and water was filled.  The price was reasonable...$25 (including tax and 22% tip) for a beer, spring rolls, and Kung Pao chicken with rice.  HIT THE SPOT!  Big portions.  We were going to do the Applebees 2 for $22 on the other side of the floor, but so happy we found here instead.  So much flavor.  Keep up the good work Ping Pang Pong!

This is a review for Togo only! As a Gorl growing up in a Chinese family, I should be accustomed to bad service at Chinese restaurants. WRONG! Customer service is terrible. I've never been this upset at waiters and waitresses. They were rude and even when I explained I was just following what the other waitress had said, the guy and another waitress have me the look like I was trash and proceeded to make me feel even worse. Never coming back again. 

As for the food, I came to try the shumai, the pork ones and har gow which are the shrimp dumplings after reading many good reviews and my friends telling me about this place. Aside from the service, the food itself was nothing outstanding. The taste was alright for the shrimp dumplings but for the shumai, it was like chewing malleable rubber. Each dumpling was like a small toy! I think that surprised me the most. For those who want to try dimsum and absolutely can't get any better, this place is okay, but for sure, there are much better options for me here in SoCal.

For some reason dim sum has been our favorite thing to do on Sunday mornings since we lived in San Francisco. We have explored most of the experiences around Las Vegas and find that Ping, Pang Pong does the best job. Not being a fan of standing in line, we get there close to the opening time at 10:30am. I also think that most of this food is prepared in advance so it is most likely freshest when the doors open. Other than China Mama, this has been the second best hot&sour soup that we have had in the area, but it does depend on which cook is making it, we have been disappointed from time to time. Also, watch out for the snails! I don't think the use good techniques for cleaning them prior to cooking, and they have been gritty and foul tasting. Don't be shocked by the inattentive and rude service, that's how they treat everyone and the price you pay if you want to enjoy authentic Chinese cooking!

Food was very good. We had the Singapore noodles, Chicken lo mein, Har Gao, Pot stickers, and Orange chicken.
All fresh and properly prepared. If you want the hot oil and mustard just ask them to bring it for you. Ambiance is nice, open kitchen so it can be a bit noisy. Plenty of Asian cliental so always a good sign. Prices are reasonable given the venue. A classy place with great food.

On our trip to Vegas last week we stayed at The Rio. On Tuesday night they experienced a gas line break which effected all of the restaurants on the property. After a while we decided to walk over to the Gold Coast and try their buffet. While walking over I noticed the sign for Ping Pang Pong's and I remember seeing great reviews for the place. My husband was excited because he had been in the mood for Chinese food. 

After arriving at the restaurant and being seated the server came and took our order. Mind you there were only 4 of us and we decided on just a few items: The Kung Pao Chicken, Beef and Broccoli and fried rice. After we placed our order we were brought the waters that we requested. An hour later we still did not have our food. We tried a number of times to flag down our server or anyone that could tell us what was up with our food...we were basically ignored. 

We ended up just getting up and walking out....

So I can't really give a review on the food but their service get's an all time low for me.
I come here all the time for the garlic frog legs cant find them anywhere else like it. The breading is light and the legs are always big.

Went there on a Monday morning for Dim Sum because of the reviews I heard on the web.  Was a little disappointed cause I felt that I've been to better Dim Sum places in Los Angeles.  There was nothing special about the dim sum selection, quality and price.  Maybe going there on a weekday is a miss and weekend is better.  But I've eaten and experienced dim sum better.

Ended up here on a random night craving authentic Chinese food- not glorified Vegas fancy schmancy Asian- and it exceeded all expectations.  

Had the roast crispy skin whole chicken and it was probably the best chicken I've ever had - juicy moist flavorful and crispy skin on the outside.  I could've had the entire chicken!  Also had the pea sprouts, deep fried sea bass and roast pork belly - all amazing.  I'm Chinese and I've had my share of Chinese food ;) and this is some
of the best!  

PS- this is a real Chinese restaurant so people who are expecting impeccable 5-star service are unrealistic - go to the aforementioned places I talked about instead.  Let's be real- You're never going to get that kind of service here. You will get efficient and courteous service and that's all you could really ask for, people!

This place was rated the best Chinese in the country, not sure I would go that far, but i like the food nevertheless. I want to give this guys 10 stars so bad, but their service is just AWFUL, TERRIBLE (Like most of Chinese restaurants in town). Couldn't care less how busy they are, add more personnel dang it, customers should be your UTMOST focus.

11/6/17: Service is much appreciated now. Food is still great.

The wait wasn't too bad on Christmas Day, the food was decent but the customer service was lacking. We requested a few items and the waiters said they will check on it and never came back with any of the dishes. My friend got fed up and we were all hungry that he had to individually chase down each cart to get what he wanted. We requested for a certain congee and the waiters like kitchens closed yet the other waiters around us were still taking kitchen orders. When we flagged down another waiter we were able to order without any problems. The first waiter told us they didn't have that congee and then we hear the workers who are about to eat lunch say to each other "oh there's blah blah congee do u want" my whole table turned around and was like wth? If you don't mind decent dimsum with hit or miss service by all means come here

Maybe because I am in Vegas and are fed up with resort-type pseudo Chinese food that cost a fortune so whenever I encounter a dim sum restaurant that's half-way decent, I don't mind giving it a higher rating.

Ping Pang Pong - let's just called it PPP - is also located within a Casino, namely the Gold Coast. The one big differentiation about this restaurant as opposed to others is that it's located far off the strip so the patrons are not visitors that just happen to walk by here. Most of the customers appear to be locals who drove here for the food.

For the most part the dishes are pretty tasty and fresh with high turnover rate. The roast duck was succulent, the salt and pepper smelt and the baked BBQ pork puff were delicious. We ordered a plate of stir-fried pea sprout greens and it was cooked just right. 

One of the desserts was recommended by the restaurant and they are these red bean filled circular donut-like pastries dusted with granulated sugar. I find them to be overrated as the crust was dry and the filling was overly sweet.

Other than that PPP is a good place to go in Vegas for dim sum.

Lots of diff choices and pretty legit.

Go to dimsum while in town .. Must gets include: turnip cake , calamari, roast duck, shu Mai and fried steam pork bun.

Always a good idea to be early to avoid the lines ..
This is where I go for dim sum when I'm in vegas.   I would give them four stars if they had more variety.

Ping Pang Pong's name sounds almost like a racist joke... But besides that, I just don't really like this restaurant, and especially not for dim sum. 

The wait to get in (especially during peak dim sum day which is Sunday) was about an hour for us but I'm sure it varies on the day. We sat at a table where we could see the line -- it was continually long up until we left at around 2pm. With all the waiting and the lines, you would think this place is really off the chain. 

No! It wasn't. Food was mediocre and the actual restaurant is quite small. It seemed like the carts were scarce and we were constantly stopping the same carts over and over again. Price was decent but not worth the money for the so-so food. 

I wanted to like Ping Pang Pong... Everyone, even locals, have told me this place is good but I didn't like it. I've heard people say Las Vegas lacks authentic and delicious dim sum places and PPP is not the place to find it.

This place was packed for dim sum on a Friday morning. I thought the price for average for dim sum, nothing too expensive and meets LA price standards. I read someone else's comments about expensive dim sum, it was about 2.50 a bin. They have a good selection and you can order other foods too. I would come back.

The most important thing for a restaurant is food safety and clean. See what I got from my dish. Other bugs maybe still forgivable. But cockroach means this restaurant is really dirty nasty and not take their kitchen clean job seriously.

I was majorly disappointed at this DIMSUM place.  To read the reviews about this place and  my gf telling me it is good there...I was willing to go through the smoky smell of the casino just to have a taste of my favorite type of Chinese Meal.
The place was rather small.  I was expecting bigger.  So with a smaller place...there were less carts to go around and less choices.  It took a while before the chow mein came to the table and was not one of the choices on the cart.  
The custard bun was not filled with custard which disappointed my son. 
The othere dishes was ok and not even worth talking about much.  
They did not come around to see if we needed refills on our drinks.  My son actually had to go to the ladies in the front (cashier) to ask for refills. 

Overall our experience in PING PANG PONG was not good and so far my recommendations still to go to ORCHIDS GARDEN.

The price- outrageous!!!!  For what we were charged....I have paid for 3 people at Orchids. 

Atmosphere- mediocre.
Food-blah,dry, not much choices
Price-Outrageous
Reviews-overrated
location-sucky smelly casino to go through
service-sucky.not attentiveed.

Probably "THE" best Chinese restaurant we've been to. 
Lunch has your typical dim sum selections and are all good.
Dinner menu is always consistent all the times we've been there. 
Gobo beef, Mongolian beef, beef flat rice noodles
Salt & pepper pork chops
Shrimp fried rice
Hong Kong style won ton noodles is just to name a few favorites that are all great dishes!
Closes at 3am is always a great thing for late night dining.

The Chinese Dim Sum during lunch is understandably busy. If you are into trying different things and different cuisine, this is a must stop for locals and visitors alike. If you are there for the food, it's great. If you are there to be wowed by Bellagio style service, you're obviously at the wrong place but it will work, no complaints from me.

I will definitely return to more during the week to escape the holiday rush. By far the most authentic and tasty place in Las Vegas. The price is on par with those other Dim Sum joints in town but much more tastier and popular. If you're down for a quick lunch, swing right in during non holiday hours! Clean, delicious, and fast: trifecta for great Chinese food!

Decided to write up a review after eaten here about a dozen times!  Food here is as authentic Chinese as you can get!  Located in the Gold Coast Hotel/Casino,  just blocks away from "Little Chinatown", this place has some of the best wonton noodle soup around!!  Wontons are a good size with an awesome flavorful pork mixture.  

If there's one dish that I can eat for lunch and dinner, it's the crispy roasted chicken... 1/2 chicken roasted so the skin is just a little crispy and the meat is just infused with this braised sweet chili soy sauce.  Pair this over steamed rice and I'll salivate over this every time!

Every restaurant has their take on orange peel chicken... and this dish is done well here.  Chicken is lightly battered, deep fried and lightly coated with a fragrant sweet orange sauce.  You won't find a pool of orange goopy sauce on the bottom of the plate!

If you're going to make a trip to a chinese restaurant near Spring Mountain Road, Ping Pong Pang is just a couple blocks away and is definitely worth going to!

My absoulte fave chinese restaurant is Sam Woo in Alahambra Ca, i give that restaurant 10 out of 10 in terms of taste, as I dont live there i have been hard pressed to find a good chinese restaurant  in Vegas, i went to PPP only cause i had a coupon, i will say the dim sum is good, but way overpriced, , today i ordered off the menu and was dissapointed the food just tastes average at best, out of 10 stars for tatse, i would give it 3.5, it will be a looong time before i return.

I never ever thought that a Chinese restaurant is located inside the casino. I came here yesterday with a friend of mine to have dinner, We ordered walnut shrimps, beef medallion and Cantonese sausage fried rice,we had to wait quite long for the service, the food tastes good, I love the texture of fried rice, and definitely recommended.   the price is a little bit expensive compared to other in town, I heard that dim sum here is the best in Las Vegas, next time I will try then

Beware of unexpected overcharge when they total the bill (charging for special item when it was a small item on the original bill)!

First visit to this restaurant yesterday, here is my takes:

Pros:
1. Nice dcor.
2. Dishes are "on the average" slightly better. Individual dishes can be better or worse than an average dim sum place. 
3. The soy paper roll was more tasty than the one I used to have.
4. They do fill your teapot regularly.

Cons:
1. Accounting for quantity, price of most dishes are 50% to 100% more expensive than the regular dim sum place I go to.  So unless money is no subject to you, it may not be worth it.

2. Some dishes are not hot. The stuffed pepper I had was lukewarm, which made for a much lesser dining experience. I passed on the pot sticker for that reason, knowing it has been sitting on the cart as long as the stuffed pepper. Some dishes really do not taste the same when they are not hot. At this price level, one certainly expect more.

3. The Har Gow is 50% more expensive and not bigger nor better. My 7 years old label it as yucky and stop eating it after she had one! Why? She said the skin is soggy. Har Gow has been her favorite dish at our regular dim sum place and she usually finish 4 in a single setting, not this time.

4. The baked bbq pork bun taste sticky, and is small, though only 20% more expensive.

5. The waiter made no attempt to write down or understand what we want when we first sat down (we asked for 4 bowls, a pot of water and a pot of tea, plastic spoons and forks for the kids, the last three items were omitted by him) and came back with half of the items we wanted. We were left waiting, not knowing if he is going to come back with the other items, he never did.

6.. Last but not the least, the check! They overcharged me when they totaled the bill by charging Small dim sum(labelled as A)  as special dim sum (labelled as D), a difference of $3 per dish plus tax.  I do not know how that can be an honest mistake, A and D are not next to each other. 
Is it intentional? That is certainly fruit for thought. Most customers do not check their bill and would never know.   I go to other dim sum restaurants frequently (at least once a week, sometimes 3 times) and never had any billing error (I am one of the rare few who check my bills regularly). Ping Pong Pang is one for one in the department of inflating the charge at the cash register. When it was pointed out to them and  they came back with the correct bill, there was no "I am sorry for the error". It certainly left a bad taste in my mouth. To make a billing mistake and not apologize for it certainly leaves a lot to be desired.
It was a bit overrated. I skipped going to Chinatown to check this place out. I'll keep driving a few blocks over next time I want Asian cuisine.

Came here twice on consecutive days for dim sum, which says something about the food. It's super good. Everything you'd expect for dim sum, plus some. Also, you can order off the menu. This place is very reasonably priced.

However, be prepared for a long wait if you come between the hours of 11am to 1pm. We got there a little before 11, and didn't sit down until 12:15. The line moves pretty slowly. The cutoff time is 3pm, and that's the exact time they stop coming around with carts. On the second day, we got there around 2:30 thinking we had some time, but they stopped serving soon after. The waitress was nice enough to give us a small plate on the house.

The service is not the best. The busboys who take your order for drinks take forever to refill ice water, as well as hot water for tea. When we asked about refills as he was passing, he seemed really pissed. Sour attitude throughout the meal. However, the ladies who come around with the dim sum carts are pretty friendly, and although it may not be their job, if you ask them about refills or missing utensils, they will make sure you get it right away.

It's a little far of a walk from the Strip, but we walked the 1 mile with no problems. The weird pedestrian walkway bridge makes it seem longer. You can take the free shuttle from Paris, Bally, or Harrahs to and from Rio, the casino next door.
Food is good. For me most dishes can feed 3 or 4 people.   Dim sum are great appetizer.   4 dim sum plates and 3 main course items , $85.00

Chinese is not my favorite cuisine but my boyfriend is Cantonese and I agreed to go with him to one Chinese restaurant on our trip to Las Vegas. We visited Chinatown and this restaurant was recommended by a couple of ladies working in one of the stores. One of the ladies said the food is very fresh because it turns over quickly, unlike the restaurants in Chinatown. I do like fried rice and I ordered mine with shrimp and pork. It was actually very well made and delicious. We couldn't take leftovers home because we were traveling but I surprised myself and actually ate the whole thing! My boyfriend had fish rice soup and some other entrees and enjoyed it all.
Great authentic food, always comes fast and fresh. If you are only accustomed to americanised Asian food then this is not your place.  I love coming here.

I think this is the most authentic Cantonese Dim Sum restaurant inside a Las Vegas Casino and Hotel.  Dim Sum 10am to 3pm

Price:  Fair
Food:  Overall is good
*Shrimp Ball - Good
*Chicken Feet - Below Average because it is not well done enough
*Chicken with mushroom over rice in a bamboo container - Not good (There were very little chicken on top of the bamboo container and it tasted frozen and stalled.  The rice is too dry.)  Don't order this dish.
*Lau Sa Bau (Sweet bun with yellow filling) - Bad.  The bun part is fine but the filling is awful.  The filling should be in bright yellow color and a light sweet taste to it.  When I bit into it, it appeared in this orange color and the taste is funny.  So, don't order this either.
*Steamed Spare Ribs - Ok and very oily and fatty.
Service:  Excellent
Environment:  Comfortable

I will check my parents into this hotel next time for it's Asian themed and catering services.  My parents will love the convenient of this hotel and restaurant.

Okay, I really did like the the interior part of the restaurant, because it made me feel like I was in a Rush Hour movie. It's definitely a beautiful restaurant! 

We were one of the first tables that arrived when they opened and to my disappointment, not all the dim sum items were out yet. Therefore, we had very few choices. The dim sum here was definitely more expensive ($4-$10), but it was delicious! 

Um, I'm not a huge fan of the service. It all felt very passive aggressive and no one smiled. Our waitress had a RBF (resting bitch face) the whole time serving us. 

Overall, It was a decent experience.

I've never been a fan of eating dim sum but I was quite impressed with the dim sum here.  If you need a dim sum fix in Vegas, this is the place to go.  My favorites are the white tripe dish and the fried chicken wings.  I also really liked the bbq pork fried rice and shrimp dumplings.  I will definitely be back the next time I'm in town.

Vegas doesn't boat of exceptional dim sum restaurants like Los Angeles and San Francisco, but Ping Pang Pong serves up some pretty good dim sum and fast!  Got our party of 6 seated within 15 minutes on a Saturday for lunch.  We picked out our dim sum shortly after getting seated and before our tea arrived.  The restaurant is cozy - not more than 20 tables (just a guess).

An overrated stinkhole that failed to deliver good service and food. I wanted to leave this place as soon as we got the check. I looked on at gamblers with envy, at least they had the potential to get their money back. The glitzy massive billboards and numerous reviews that laud this place as one of the best Chinese food restaurants are misleading. Maybe that distinction was right in the past but I couldn't find anything that would qualify as "best".  I should've known with a name like Ping Pang Pong. 

The problems began in the beginning. Once seated we were ignored for a good time and my sister had to get up and ask for drinks. The food that came was unmemorable and smelled odd, even for a Chinese restaurant. The Cantonese Princess Chicken was cold, bony, and slathered in oil. Our noodle dish was over seasoned with curry powder and had a pungent odor. It left my stomache feeling uneasy as I was driving home. The only food I liked was the sauteed Chinese brocolli and soup, unfortunately that's not enough to warrant a visit. Overall, I wouldn't recommend coming here especially when there are plenty of better options in the valley.
Food was okay, but the noise level made it almost unbearable.......servers are not warning people about dim sum having seafood in it..................

Not great.  Not terrible.  We all presumed that a Chinese restaurant catering to what appeared on this night to be 95% Asian community would have hit all the right notes.

San Pan Tiger Prawns were very good.  Head, legs, and tail on.  Spiced just right.  Fried enough that legs crunched to powder and head held together and juicy.

Ma Po Tofu with Pork was edible.  Not good.  There were flavors missing.  The heat was right with Szechuan pepper.  Its just that no other flavors seemed present.  Lots of tofu not enough pork. Bland.

Noodles were completely tasteless.

Mo Shoo Pork was excellent.  No question.  It came as an appetizer.  Two large pre-filled rices pancakes.  At first bite i realized it needed Hoisin sauce. The next bite made me realize I needn't ask for it as it was already in there.  Wood ear mushrooms even.  Plenty of pork and veggies.

The price for all this was under $60.  Myself and two Partners-in-Dine would have been happier if the food tasted as good as those few dishes did.

When we were ready to pay our check there were no servers on the floor. We realized an entire table of six or seven eating dinner one table over from ours were the entirety of floor STAFF having dinner together.

We had to get up and pay at the register waiting in line behind several other diners waiting to pay their bills.  I think under normal circumstances we would have paid our server.  What happened tonight I am not sure.

I don't believe any of us were so in love or even like with our food that we would go out of our way to return.
Great dim sum, shady service. what do you really expect, come on.

My family used to come here almost every weekend, now when it comes up we need to ask ourselves if we are prepared to deal with what comes with dining there. The food is always cold and if you ask for fresh they act like they dont understand or they will microwave it and say its fresh. I enjoy the coconut rolls, there is 2 to an order but one is always an old one and you can tell because the paper is baked on the bottom of the old one. Again if you ask for fresh there is confusion. Now for this next problem im just going to say it like it is...the worst tables in the place usually go to the people who arent asian. If youve been here enough you know its true. Also there is no way to tell what you are being charged for they use a stamp system and its not even in english. So if you like paying 60 to 80 bucks for cold, old, reheated food and like being mistreated and ignored this is your place.

love this food..wonderful that this place stays open til 3am,yaaaahhhyyyy!!
best salt & pepper shrimp eeevvvveeeerrrr.

Definitely come here for the dim sum and come early. As there can be quite a wait. Service wasn't spot on as it took a bit of time to get seated even when at this early time not all the tables were filled. Also took some time to get the attention of the service staff to get orders in. In the end the standout here is the dim sum. A large variety of various dim sum platters. Some you'll only find as specialty items in Asia and not found in the states. Large portions as well for a dimsum plate so you get value for your buck. Nicely flavored shrimp dumplings and chinese meatballs. They had a great tofu dessert. Served hot in a bowl with sugar syrup. Delicious shrimp and beef churn fun. Freshly baked egg tarts that were still hot and flakey. Their beef chow fun was also very good with lots of ingredients and can serve a large group. If in Vegas and hankering for some dim sum i would definitely come here. Would be 4 stars on food alone if not for the service.

Inconveniently located about as far away from the parking at Goldcoast as you can get - this restaurant is great if you want to go to a dodgy casino and overpay for just-alright Chinese food. The bill came to $90 for 4 people and no one was all that impressed.  Don't believe their signs that this is the best Chinese food in Las Vegas.  It isn't.

Make sure to check out the menu on Goldcoast's website that they haven't updated since 2006 so your guests can be disappointed that they no longer have Oxtail soup.

Service is terrible. Food was good. Came here at the old location in the casino before and enjoyed it. Tried it today but the service was very poor. First, at the hostess desk, no one even looked up for about 45 seconds then just pointed and said wait. About 2 minutes later someone comes around the corner and says something like " let go" so I followed. She took me to a table. No menu. I waited for over 5 minutes before I even saw an attendant. She brought a menu and asked for my drink order. Didn't come back for more than 10 minutes and only wanted to deliver my water. I told her I was ready to order. She seemed annoyed but took my order. Kung Pao chicken and Night Fried Rice. A few minutes later another woman came to deliver good, that i did not order. I dont know if she didnt speak english, but, i told her no. Not mine. She said yes, yes and stared at me. Finally when i handed it back to her she got the idea. It was for tbe ladt next to me. Very unfriendly and almost rude staff. Food came quickly and it was hot and fresh. Never saw the waitress again. I was finally refilled on my water by a manager of some sort who was very nice. She brought my water back and I waited probably 10 more minutes before someone came back to get my credit card. They were busy but not full and really no excuse for service level.
It was more than an hour wait. The food was good but the service was just off. We had the same 3 carts the whole hour we were there. We asked for certain dishes multiple times but it never came.

Where: The Gold Coast Casino.
What: Amazing Chinese food!!!

Yes, four stars given!!!
 
I've eaten at some really great Chinese restaurants in my time. All over the San Gabriel Valley, OC, Los Angeles, San Francisco, etc, etc.

 This place amazed me! There is TRULY great Chinese food in Vegas, and Dim Sum as well! 
 
Located in the Gold Coast, this place was filled with Asians devouring Dim Sum for breakfast. 
 
Siu Mai.
Har Gow.
Bean Curd rolls.
Fried Taro thing.
Beef Meat Ball. 
Other misc. Dim Sum.
 Lop Chong Fried Rice.
 Low Mein.

 All frickin amazing. I'd put this place up against some of the places in the So. Cal/No. Cal area. 

 Definitely worth a try!!!
Delicious chinese food.  You know a restaurant is good when the majority of the customers are that nationality.  Not the best in terms of atmosphere, but who cares when the food is delish.

How can you not love the name of this restaurant.  "Ping Pang Pong"?  Come ON.

Just saying it makes one all smiley.

Ping Pang Pong Ping Pang Pong Ping Pang Pong Ping Pang Pong Ping Pang Pong...

See?  Don't even front.  You're grinning right now-- or at least cracking a smile too.  :P

So I just had to check it out.

Chicken Congee.  They make special!  (For you?)  Yes, for me.

Usually I don't care for runny, Cantonese style rice gruel.  Plain, thick, bright white porridge is what makes my palate happiest.  Chicken bits, soup colour and mystery stuff that I myself did not place in the cooked down rice, just weirds me out... sorry.  Blame it on my boring Taiwanese-Japanese influenced upbringing.

However.  What's the point of being in Vegas, if you don't take chances?  In this case, I gambled on trying it.  And it paid off.  In my tummy.

This congee item wasn't on the menu, but it was kind of them to cook it up.  The waitress suggested it.  Perhaps she took one look at my haggardness and thought I needed some.

It was quite good.  Wor Wonton Soup was also basic and tasty.  Will have to try the dim sum this place is known for, next time.

The soups here were a good way to wind down a full day of travel and eating on the run.

Thank you Ping Pang Pong!

PINGing with excitement, we were thrilled to try out some dim sum while in Vegas. We ate here with some friends that had lived in Vegas and said this was one of the best places for dim sum. We arrived here around noon, and there was a bit of a wait, since there is limited space in the restaurant, especially for large parties of more than 4. Ignoring our PANGs of hunger, we waited patiently. It probably took us about 20-30 minutes to get seated. 

While the selection is more limited than other dim sum restaurants, they do you have your standard dim sum items like shu mai, sticky rice in lotus leaf, fried taro cake, chicken feet, spare ribs, congee, and bao. 

The items were hot, and fresh tasting. The carts went by at a decent rate, but we were warned that you should get any items you wanted while the cart was there, since you might not see that cart again. Prices were a bit high compared to other restaurants I've eaten at (3-4 dollars per item average), but that was to be expected for dim sum in a Vegas casino.

Service was a bit spotty, but to be expected since the restaurant was filled to capacity with hungry diners. Waiters were buzzing back and forth, like a ball in a PONG game, filling water, getting more tea, and getting people's checks.
