I took many more photos...just click the picture link on the top of the review if you would like to check them out.

They are located inside Gold Coast Casino! Check it out for late afternoon dim sum!

This has to be one of my favorite places to eat when in vegas. Yes the menu might not seen as extensive as other Chinese places one might be used to, but the food taste great and prices are decent for hotel restaurant. We always get the walnut prawns and the Cantonese noodles. Sometimes try something new. Haven't had a bad experience here yet, and can get pretty crowded on weekend nights

My family needed a break from the gluttony of the buffets so we came here on a weekend morning. Having eaten dim sum at several Chinese joints in the SF bay area, I was somewhat disappointed in this place. But I do agree with some of the other reviewers that this is probably one of the better places for dim sum in all of Vegas.

They have all the usual favorites: har gow, shiu mai, spareribs, hom gok, taro puffs, sesame balls, egg tarts, gai lan, etc. We ordered a couple items (noodles and veggies) off the non-dim sum menu (limited items) but  found them to kind of pricey for what they were.

They definitely need more staff as there were often 2-3 carts just sitting in a corner of the restaurant full of fresh plates going cold. Meanwhile, patrons were  looking impatiently all around for the next cart to come around.

Total price for about 7-8 small plates plus noodles/veggies came to about $55 w/o tip for 4 people. Pretty standard.

PUKE!!!!!!! Go hit Chia Town aka Spring Mountain Rd from "The Strip up to Decatur" and you are garunteed to have better food. Not to mention the waiter charged me twice for my melee which I discovered two days later looking at a bank statement. Went in to talk to the manager, he was nice. but was unable to help me. DONT EAT HERE

Ive been going here for years and the food has always stayed consistent. I love the dim sum cart that comes around! The food from the menu is also delicious. I love Wor Won Ton soup. The broth from Ping is so clear but it was lacking in flavor. I love to see a clear broth but it literally tasted like salted water. Everything in the soup(bok choy, pork, the chicken) was excellent. Oh and the wontons were some of the best that Ive had. Alas....this was not enough happiness to make up for the fact that I waited almost an hour (behind 5 different families) just to eat. While waiting I stood there watching multiple tables just kind of sitting there. Napkins on there plates. Just drinking water. They were there while I waited in line and they were there when I paid my receipt. It was absolutely ridiculous. They literally sat there for 2 hours watching all the people waiting in line to get into this place to eat.

 If the food was just a tiny bit better I dont think I would have been so annoyed. Im giving this place 3 stars because somebody should have told these people to order some food or get out. It was ridiculous.

I've never actually had dim sum before, and this place came highly recommended.  My friend got there before me and waited in line to get us a table at lunch.  (Yes, there seems to be a line there. Always.)  The place is loud and busy, and nothing too fancy- wouldn't be much a date spot, but delicious to go for lunch or dinner with a friend. servers come by with carts of many dish options and you can choose which small plates you would like to get.  We ordered about 4-5 plates and the bill was about $30.  Overall, very good, affordable, and a fun dining experience.
Can't believe I only discovered this place on my most recent visit in July.  Dim sum was great and the orange beef was off the hook.

The wait is pretty long even when they opened at 10. I went at around 10:30 and the place is packed and a line. The dim sum here is good, but they don't have a big selection. Service is average for a Chinese place. Use your hand to flag the waiter if I want anything.
Thought this place would have some good dim sum... But i was wrong. Over priced and not that good. Save your money.

Dim sum on Halloween. Hooray!

Ping Pang Pong never disappoints. They have all the usual dim sum suspects plus a few of their own creations. The cart pushers are always friendly and patient. 

The 2 of us came in thinking "Let's just drink some tea and grab a couple of plates to snack on." 

9 plates later .. No ragrets! Haha what's done is done. The damage came to $45 for 2 people before tip. Pricier than the places not in casinos but so much tastier. They don't hold back adding special little touches that make all the difference

-Beef balls w/ Worschershrdshire sauce - small but packed with flavor and bits of scallions
-Shu Mai - has tasty orange stuff on top. Could be fish eggs 
-Rice noodle rolls - moist and the noodle thickness was perfect
-Pork spare ribs - black bean oil sauce with chilis nomm
-Roast pork - stamped on the ticket under "special" and it was! Crispy skin, moist on inside without too much fatty part

In my book nowhere else in Vegas compares when it comes to dim sum.

Looks like they took my favorite Crispy Seafood Noodles off the menu since the renovation, but Ping Pang Pong is still a sure bet for late-night Chinese food in Las Vegas. 

Recommended: Enoki Mushroom With Pickled Snow Cabbage And Tofu, $12.95. Curry Pineapple Seafood Fried Rice, $13.95.

See it all here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wOSNK-szJRU

This used to be our late night Chinese spot, and by late night, I mean after Noodle Exchange across the hallway closes because the Exchange is a tastier experience. However, we stopped going because the food started to make our bellies feel a little unhappy. We could never identify why exactly, but we decided to relocate our late night Chinese adventures to Spring Mountain Road. However, last night, we happened to be booking up Flamingo and decided to give it another chance because for several months straight I had a serious Wrinkled Green Bean addiction, and I wanted to go back for another round.

I knew immediately I would be ordering the Wrinkled Green Beans with some extra wrinkles, and I also ordered some basic chicken soft noodles. The service was a little slow, but friendly. Our waiter smiled when I told him I liked them "really wrinkly." My husband ordered a noodle soup.

The green beans had a nice flavor, but they were pretty greasy and some of the magic flavor (described as a Chinese tarragon) was missing. The noodles were brown from soy sauce, which isn't my preference. Plus, the noodles lacked the amount of veggies that you often get in a noodle dish. A few slivers of cabbage, some hidden bean sprouts, but no carrots. And, the noodles were a bit chewy. The noodles were no comparison to the same dish at Noodle Exchange just across the way. Everything just seemed a tad too heavy, and my husband wasn't in love with his soup. He said, "It wasn't bad."

I may be willing to go back for dim sum, as I have yet to try that, but for other times, I am afraid last night reminded me why we had stopped visiting.

I was worried about having to make a long time after reading other reviews, but luckily for us, we only had to wait about 20 minutes before getting seated.  It does help to only have a party of 2!  

They had every one of my favorite dim sum dishes (turnip cake, tripe, bbq pork rice noodles, lobster claws) and even some new dishes too.

The quality of the dim sum was pretty good, not the best but better than a lot of places in Orange county.  

The prices were decent too, i think it ranged from $2-6 a dish.  We stuffed ourselves for $30.

avoid this place as much as you can. we waited for almost 45min to an hour for our food and when we got it it's pretty much cold .. and i'm so mad to eat so i just end up just looking at the food and being disappointed .

This place takes the cake when it comes to Chinese food! Aaah ! Chow many choices! Mom noms. Sooo good! This place gets packed and there Can be a line here. That itself tells you it is dernnnnnn goodie.  Dim sum... perfect for me. I don't eat meat but I like a lot of stuff here . Came here with my family for my cousins birthday we had a blast. Pictures show below. Good menu too if you don't wish to gave dim sum. I love this place I've been here a few times. Happy dimsuming! ( ehh no such word but you got it ) :)

We were looking for a Chinese Restaurant that serves Dim Sum late.  We stumbled across this restaurant in the Gold Coast Casino around 1:30 am.  At first we didn't know if they were closing.  No one acknowledged us for a good five (felt like 10) minutes, and nobody else was waiting.  There was no staff in sight to welcome us or take our name.  Right before walking away, someone finally confronts us.  Because we were hungry and lazy, we ended up waiting another 5 minutes since the place was packed.  

Once we sat down, service was tolerable.  Our drink refills came frequently, and the food was prepared quickly.  We got our Dim Sum fix with Shu Mai and Hargow...pretty average.  Everything else (Fu Chow Fried Rice, Black Pepper Beef, Kung Pau Chicken, and Walnut Prawns) exceeded the standard except for the Hot & Sour Soup.
  
Bad start...but good finish..

We were craving dim sum for dinner and heard from friends this place was one of the best in town. Their dinner dim sum menu is limited to 8-10 items and char siu bao is not on it. We were disappointed about that but the dim sum did have was really good. I recommend the baked Bbq pork bun. The bun was flaky and fresh out of the oven. 

Since most of our dim sum favorites were not on the dinner menu, we ended up getting the walnut shrimp and the yang chow fried rice. Both were really good and we left happy.

We had just had a disappointing Dim Sum experience at another place the night before- the other place had received a very good review too, so this shook our faith in the good ol' yelp system. Fortunately, it was a fluke. Ping Pang Pong was DANG near as good as our usual haunt in Portland. The service was good, the food was great, and specialty items were quickly cooked and served to us if they weren't already on the carts. My favorite little indulgence here was the coconut custard bun. Ambrosia! Another of our favorite dim sum stables is the stuffed eggplant, har gow, and sui mai- Ping Pang Pong delivered on all of them!

Service is horrible. Food is great but they always try to sell u the unwanted dishes first and the common dim sum dishes they never have available til late. Overall this is my 6th time here n every time it's like this no different. Really poor service
I just loveLoveLOVE this place. I like everything I ordered in the menu so far. Make sure you're not hungry if you wanna eat here because you have to stand in line

Methink not going back. No return. Horrible customer service. I have dine-in the afternoons & evenings, not busy times & I still waited for my food for 30 minutes. Here is what I noticed, the local chinese residents of las vegas order there food to-go. The cooks & servers will prepare the to-go orders first before they serve the customers who are eating at the restaurant. That is why customers dining in are waiting for 30 minutes. Almost all the food menu are served with lots of MSG & salted ingredients, yes am saying too salty. The touch of chinese cuisine has disappeared. The lady night manager needs to be replaced. She enjoys arguing customers at night. Messed up!

My family and I had decided to give this place a try in the afternoon on a Tuesday. The dim sum here is subpar. 80% of the dishes came out cold, there's nothing worst then biting into a cold bbq pork bun with hard crust and cold centre. Dishes are small and taste is very one dimension. There's $1 charge per person on tea/water and 15% gratuity on large group. Price on dishes are $2.88 to $9.98. On average dishes are $5.88 such as pork and shrimp dumplings, spare ribs, rice crepe, etc. the typical must have at a dim sum.

The only redeemable quality is its cleanliest, otherwise, it's a failing grade on service, food quality, taste/flavor, price, and portion size.

A hidden gem in Vegas. We had 12 in our party and had a round table with a Lazy Susan. Perfect for family style. The Duck, Lamb, MongolianBeef and Orange Chicken were awesome. The place has elegance and sophistication yet is very affordable. As far as service goes no news is good news. Servers always had our food and drinks coming but never noticed they were there. Great place for an event or occasion. Ours was a graduation dinner.
One of the BEST fishes I have ever tasted. The Chilean sea bass 10oz is soooo good. A+ not even joking.

Items Selected:
Crispy Duck with Roasted Peanuts
Pork Belly with Roasted Peanuts
Shrimp Ball with Mayo
Chive Dumpling
Almond Coated Shrimp with Mayo
Steamed Pork Bun
Har Gow
Shumai
Baked Pork Bun
Baked Coconut Bun
Egg Custard
Stuffed Eggplant
Pan Fried Red Bean Cake
Red Bean Donut
Red Bean Bun

Found inside the Gold Coast Casino, and said by some to offer the best Dim Sum in a City oft lamented for lacking anything on par with other locations of similar size, it was with three friends that an 11:00am arrival was planned at Ping Pang Pong - one showing up far later than the rest, but really not missing much as the majority of items proved mediocre to decent at best, though service was admittedly far superior to several spots on Spring Mountain Road...perhaps to be expected considering the price.

Served in traditional cart format, the table provided cattycorner the kitchen giving a good vantage of carts being loaded with fresh items throughout the duration of a two-hour stay, Ping Pang Pong features most of the usual suspects with minimal variation and taking a slow-but-prudent approach to ordering as the restaurant sat almost universally full it was with teas both iced and hot that service began, a duo of crispy duck and supple pork each served with peanuts and complimentary sauces proving well roasted and full of flavor, though the former was riddled with bones that left some pieces virtually devoid of meat.

Passing on snails that later went half-uneaten by the tardy member of the party, course two featured fried shrimp balls with a sidecar of creamy mayo along with surprisingly delicate and aromatic chive dumplings that rivaled the best found anywhere in town, and moving onward to a trio of plump crustaceans covered in sliced almonds it was here that the savory highpoints of the afternoon were found, the freshness of each item assured by the good fortune of location though the increasing smell of cooking oil and gas would eventually render that impression unsound.

Underwhelmed by both shumai and har gow with skins that trended too thick, and personally finding both styles of pork buns almost 'dessert like' given the significant amount of sugar present in the sauce, it was a bit of a surprise that the lightly set egg custards were almost entirely natural in flavor atop flaky buttered pastry, a duo of coconut buns ordered as the first of several sweets equally impressive without the gloppy filling that sometimes ruins the texture of the bun.

Adding one more savory, the soft eggplant with an herbal stuffing coated in fermented bean sauce, before going all-in on a trio of sweets to finish, suffice it to say that those fancying red bean paste are well served at Ping Pang Pong, and although items featuring both green tea, pineapple, and sesame were offered the pan fried cakes of red bean as well as baked buns and filled with the same were every bit as good as any tasted anywhere to date, the lack of pressure to turn a table while drinks were repeatedly refilled without request allowing time to linger, chat, and enjoy - an admitted rarity in during peak hours at restaurants serving in this style.

Charging approximately 25% more than other similar spots in town, and failing to nail the standards despite executing a few items quite well, Ping Pang Pong is just another average Dim-Sum joint intended to cater to the growing Asian tourist population, a better option for those confined to casinos found at nearby KJ in the Rio while those with a car would be well served to check out Chang's just a mile and a half to the North.

Highly recommend this place for Chinese Dim Sum.  It is small, hidden away inside the Gold Coast Hotel and Casino.  Very well worth it to come and visit.  Their Dim Sum is so delicious.  I love all the foods there...chicken feet, hai cau, siu mai, dumplings, porridge, tofu, mango deserts, and on and on.   Seriously, who knew you can go to Vegas and get authentic Chinese Dim Sum.  Yummy!

Poorest excuse to call this Dim Sum. Yelp rates this the highest in Vegas. Selection is sad, we have more variety in Utah with a much less Chinese population. Panda Express is more authentic. 

Service was horrible, food was over cooked as it tasted like it was steamed many hours from yesterday's leftovers.

They kept pushing around the same 3 carts over and over with less and less of a selection. This is as authentic as Mexican food is to Taco Bell. I feel sorry for the people waiting in a long line to get in, normally with a big wait you would expect awesome food. I think most of the customers were from group tours or were offered free food for staying in the run down hotel/casino, as I can't picture anyone from Asia wanting to try this place.
Love the place. They had assorted dim sum I can think of and the flavor was quite authentic. The wait time was about 25 minutes at 11am.

This is disgusting food beyond belief. I wouldn't serve these lamb chops to my dog. Because it would be cannibalism. The food was really really bad, overpriced beyond belief and downright disgusting. If you have any respect for yourself don't eat here.

One of the best dim sum meals I've ever had!  Arrived 5 minutes after they opened and almost didn't sit down because there was no one else inside.  Nearly tragic.  The service was extremely speedy and efficient.  I was able to get my favorite dim sum dishes (authentic taste) and within 15 minutes the place was packed.

Sooo they moved to a different location in the Gold Coast hotel. Really nice looking and the food was great. We had salt and pepper pork chops, young chow fried rice and chicken chow mein. Food was awesome I expected that but the service was awful. Oh my god. Usually the service is the greatest at Chinese restaurants but this place was awful. Nobody took our order even though it wasn't busy. Our server ignored us multiple times through out the night even though she saw us. That really dropped this rating down to 3. Food is really good though. Maybe it was just our server but I highly doubt it. It didn't look like management really knew what they were doing since there were what looked like 3 or 4 managers.
Dim sum was delish! Great selection and good prices. The food was fresh and not greasy. The staff was very friendly and attentive.  I will definitely be going back for more!

Hungover from a crazy night in the Heffner Suite? Walk over to ping pang pong for some awesome congee to take the sting off.

My girlfriend and I went twice over the weekend and both times they completely hit the spot with har gow, congee, and hot mustard.
Good chinese food in the middle of the dessert. Didn't see the dim sum.

We came on a friday night and got a couple individual dinner plates. I ordered the Gabo beef and beef chow fun for ~27.

- Gabo beef was very delicious Although the portion seemed small, it was very fulfilling. the meat even appeared dry, but turned out to be juicy. It was tender and quite flavorful. 
- Beef chow fun was pretty good and the portion was generous. Kind of unremarkable. Not too oily. No real unique taste.
- Free hot tea :)
- Fast service. Quick with refills.
- If you see a lot of old asian grand ma's and pop's, then you know its legit! lol
- It's pleasant enough for me to come back and try their dim sum. 
- For dinner, I'd opt for wendy's noodle cafe.

:)!
Bad service, worst hostesses and the food was horrific. Wor wonton soup blah, dim sum pork ribs ay and shanghai noodles with pork never again. Do not eat here. It was so bad I had to say.

Maybe more like 4.25.

It did win some kind of top 10 award for Chinese Restaurants in T + L magazine but other than dim sum, I haven't been to PPP for their regular menu for quite some time.   About 4 or 5 years ago, my sister swore by this place for decent Chinese food. Now it has a lot of competition. So basically, I'm just reviewing their dim sum service.

I had to explain to my husband the difference between AUTHENTIC Chinese food and Chinese food. I've learned that some (not all) that call Panda Express and PF Changs Chinese food may not like AUTHENTIC Chinese food. They are not one and the same.

There is a definite difference in quality compared to other favorite dim sum joints I've been too. PPP is hot & fresh and definitely tasty. I must emphasize HOT because that's the biggest blow for dim sum lovers - cold food! I wouldn't recommend it for 1st time dim summers though unless you speak fluent Chinese. I'm half Asian and can decipher a lot of broken English, but I've had a very difficult time figuring out what the cart ladies say is on their cart. My husband and I are not as adventurous, so we are the types that want to know what we are eating before we eat it....

But once you can identify a food by looking at it, PPP is definitely on the higher end of the spectrum for taste and quality. Their shrimp dumplings for example - are probably the best I've had and when you think about a simple dumpling is made - you have to admire that somewhere in the process, PPP does something spectacular.

The shrimp balls, shumai, pork buns, sticky pork buns - all have a little extra something that sets them above the rest.

The restaurant itself is quaint. You can see the kitchen from your table, and the a lot of what, in most places, is normally behind closed doors. Goldcoast is not the most glamorous of casinos... and the restaurant itself is still a good ways from the parking garage. But if you don't mind walking through the casino and the smoke that comes with it, the location may work for you. 

Plus, if you are a dim sum for breakfast person like me, they do open a bit earlier than a lot places around town 10:00am.

So if you enjoy dim sum, PPP is definitely a must-have on you're list. You just have to, even if it's once.

Went there on Fourth of July weekend and saw this place during my last visit in December but didn't try it then.  This time there was five of us and it was kinda late so was really glad to hear this place is open till 3am on weekends.
We were sat within five minutes of arriving and waiter took our drink orders.  She was really quiet at times but really quick.  The menu has a good amount of choices.  My recommendations is get a bowl of soup as an appetizer.  A friend who like asian spots told me once to try start off with one of the soups on the menu.   If the soup is good, then the rest of the food will be good.  We decided to try a soup that had big chunks of pork and asian veggies with had an amazing broth.
When it came time to order, we decided to get a bunch off dishes and try a little of each item.  Out of each item, I recommend trying the walnut prawns.  They are amazing!!! My brother enjoyed the roasted duck.
The place has a nice appearance and its full of Asians coming with large groups.  The table next to us was complaining about something on the order so there was a lot of arguing in Chinese, I think.  I can't wait to come back and get those walnut prawns!!  Heard they have dim sum during the lunch hours so gonna have to try that some time as well.

There's always a long wait.  Expect 30min to 1hr wait on Sunday. The shiu mai, spring rolls are great.  The desserts were awesome.  I come there mainly for the buns with sweet yellow egg custard inside.  The sweet rice wrapped inside banana leaf was also our favorite.
Customer service was not good.  The servers always rush in and out.  When we want something they always act as if they cannot help us and we have to wait for the right  food carts to come.  It was frustrating.
Even though I hate to come here because the service sucks, it is still among one og the best place for dim sum when we have a craving for it.  So we stop by maybe once a year.

This place is good for dim sum but this is the part that got them the three stars.  We had duck bbq pork ribs and broccoli at 9.95, wow that is a lot and the duck was not tasty where I would say Yummy yum yum.  The skin was not crisps.  The rubs and broccoli was good but not at that price. 


The Sui Mai's were okay I didn't like the sesame on top of the,  the hom suy gook were good but it had a string taste of dried shrimp. The meatballs were one star, not good or even soft it s texture is like fish balls which I don't like. 

One lo Mai gai, usually you get wi of the rice wrapped in bamboo leaves 
,ha gow was food.  The bbq pork steam bows and bakes were really good they were filled with plenty of meat. 

The aide chow mein was lacking bean sprouts but it guess it filled my carving as it went by many times and it was was calling my name. 

We got quite anew things but I didn't eat them all.  Someone told me that this was best in town, I have at it is pretty decent but they lack service.  We didn't get our water or tea until way later after sitting down.  The refills were scarce too.  Who expects service drink a Chinese place? I do... 

They have people in line waiting and there was another sign that said wait here.  I wasn't sure if you need to tell them the number in your party and then get in line.  I asked the people in line but they didn't understand me.  I waited for a bit which no one showed up until five minutes later, she tells me to stand in line and she will come.  Okay don't talk to me like I am an irritating you, I just wanted to check.  Besides she sat the first two people then she came back but the people in front of us decide to sit in those two seats and they get in first. Wth... What system is that but shame on the two that didn't say anything.  Okay so there are at least 90% Asian eating but I think that there must be an Asian tour bus coming around because this place has changed quite a bit. 

Good recommendation from friends eh...

2/25/17
Come to dinner and the food was yummy the service form the waiter was excellent.  He was on point tonight. 
The anchovy fried rice was good but not the better than ones in la.  Orange chicken didn't have enough vinegar but it was good.  The pork chops with the red sauce was good I would of liked the chops to have a coating on them.  The best is the spicy salt calamari.  That would get 5 stars from me.  If you like garlic and jalapeo it is perfect!! The Gro beef was good bit enough taste of basil but tender.
If you hungry don't come here it about 1 hour for bring your food out but if u like duck bone this restaurant it good for u :/ never again....

Ping Pang Pong is a go to place for when some of my friends want to get together for crab. Their style of spicy and salty is probably the best. It is all about getting well rounded flavors and plenty of food. Their razor clams and scallops on the half shell are a steal. At $8 for four and two respectively is a steal. I could eat those all night. Just be warned that your breath will be kicking. So much fried garlic goes on top of both dishes. 

PPP is a hit or miss. The green tea smoked duck was not something we enjoyed. I ended up just wanting Peking duck and was sad to see that they don't offer it. The sweet and pungent lotus roots are always a must. Add that with the three dishes I list above and you don't really need anything else. 

The dim sum here is good. It is just pricey compared to other places. 

Just be prepared. Don't expect great service. Just know something might go wrong during the meal and just move on. The food is good.
Crab claw was not  like this picture today... it was not claw sticking out, but something fake one...

After a late business conference, hubby and I decided to live on the edge and eat some dim sum at midnight. We never have the option when we're in San Diego, so we jumped at the opportunity. 

We were seated quickly, and a server took our drink order. Food was served after a few short minutes, and everything was pretty good. No major complaints here!

Such a wasted  time !!! Me and my bf we drove here late at night like 11pm - midnight i was so excited to try dim sum and it's nothing like just a couple dishes on the menu then they serve with no sauce anything on the side I mean shumai should dip with soy sauce chili sauce thing like that ? And they just give me hot sauce when I ask ,they forget to bring a glass of water to my bf  the service so bad the server not pay attention to you and he just told us order something that fast I mean I'm a server too and I understand that server should tell customer if some dishes will take time to cook but not like DON'T ORDER THIS with the face that it too long to wait and tell us to pick something else I mean if it that long and you don't want to make it why put it on the menu !!!!!    ???

Btw my friend told me dim sum here you have to go on lunch time theres a variety of dim sum and it's pretty good she agreed that service was suck anyway
Unbelievable for a cai-lang dish for $10. We will never come back to this restaurant.
Newly Renovated. Good food. Went here for lunch. The place is packed. Line gets really long. Paid about 20 bucks for 10 sets. Amazing!
White guilt told me this was some kind of racial slur against chinese people. Yelp told me it was actually a killer chinese restaurant. Yelp was right! So so so so good!

This review is about dim sum only. 

We arrived at 11:30 am and waited for 45 minutes to be seated. Choice of dim sum was not as wide as I expected, especially the desserts.

Chicken feet (4.5/5): Well-cooked with savory sauce. Nice one.
Stuffed eggplant (4.5/5): The eggplant and the stuffing absorbed the sauce, quite tasty.
BBQ pork pastry (4.5/5): I actually came here for this dish. The BBQ pork was nicely seasoned, and balanced well with the pastry.
Fried shrimp ball (4/5): The shrimp ball was chewy. It came with a sugar cane stick, so I was expecting Vietnamese-style Cho tm, but it turned out to be totally different. 
Rice roll with beef and coriander (2.5/5): The rice roll was way too thick, and the soy sauce was very bland. To finish the entire roll was suffering.

(Update)
Visited a second time for a gathering. Tried some other stuff:

Bovine offal with daikon (4/5): Savory dish, even the daikon in it was well-cooked and flavorful. 
Steamed beef ball (3.5/5): Balanced lean and fat meat, giving it nice texture. 
Milk pudding (0.5/5): The worst milk pudding I ever had in my life. At first I was surprised that the pudding got a puff pastry crown on it. The pastry wasn't really good - but it's fine, because the pudding itself was far worse. It was watery, strange-flavored, sweet but tasteless...Every bite was torturing.

Ladies pushing the cart were mostly polite and friendly. But most staff here were so busy that we could barely find someone to fill our tea. Seats were packed but acceptable.

Stopped in for a late dinner after a day of poker at the Rio. Easy walk across the street. Was quickly sat, drink ordered and after a quick review of their extensive menu, I opted for dishes I am familiar with:  war wonton soup and Singapore Rice noodles. I was not feeling adventurous to try frog legs or the live eel dish and was a little put off that they offer shark fin soup. Service was far and friendly, my ice tea never ran dry. Place was clean, well lit and not too noisy. But then it was 11:20pm. 

Soup was delicious with plenty of shrimp, chicken white meat, BBQ pork and pork filled wontons. Throw in some greens, scallions, mushrooms and it is a shareable portion. He second dish was Singapore Rice noodles. Again, plenty of meat and it arrived steaming hot. I added some red chilli paste as I found the curry spicing a little lighter than my preference. It too was delicious. 

Overall, 4 stars and a definite recommend to my friends, family and fellow Yelpers. Also, I found it to be a good value considering it is in Vegas.

Very good Dim Sum. We had the typical fare...shrimp, noodles, chicken feet, tripe and potstickers. They were friendly enough with very good service. We got there about 1:30 and for Dim Sum that's a bit late, because they start to run out of the good stuff i.e. Duck, roasted pork etc. Some of the dishes are were a bit cold but when we told them, they cooked us fresh plates. That is a big reason for the 4 rating. I'd go back it was done well

Visited the restaurant while I was in Vegas because of a recommendation. I expected much much more. Food was very salty especially the mongolian beef. I find it hard to believe that this is the best Chinese restaurant in Vegas as people claim. I tried it and don't plan on going again.

There is usually a long wait, so my boyfriend and I decided to go early.

There wasn't that much of a selection and it took about an hour after opening for food to really come out.  Once it did service was still slow.

Their lo mei gei was made with long grain rice, which I did not like.  Their food was fresh and good quality, but was lacking in taste.

Orchid Garden over Ping Pang Pong.
One of the best Chinese dim sum but the price is out of control. 4 people $138 not including tips yet.  We didn't even eat that much.

One might think, with a wacky name and being located in a casino, that Ping Pang Pong isn't going to be any good.  However, it's definitely one of the better places in town (and my favorite) for dim sum.  The restaurant is little bit small, so expect a bit of a wait on crowded days.  If you don't see a dish that you want being carted around, you can ask and they will generally make it for you.  Prices are a little bit more expensive than the other places in town, but not that much (maybe 50 cents to a dollar more per dish).

Also, I saw Johnny Chan eating here once.  If Ping Pang Pong is good enough for Johnny Chan, it's good enough for me, and probably you, too!

YUMM!!! deliciousness with every bite! I am so happy I found this place. Its a hidden gem tucked away in the Gold Coast Casino. There are many different options and all are mini servings so you can try so many different dishes...well obviously, its a dim sum! I will warn you that the Asian women servers can be mean! They don't speak any English and also have a horrible attitude. It makes me laugh though so don't get worked up, just laugh too. I have noticed they have warmed up to me because I have become a regular so now its not so bad. Overall its a fun experience, I highly recommend Ping Pang Pong.

Everything tasted bland . Veggie in garlic sauce had only broccoli N bok Choy . Noodles had no sauce n chicken fried rice had some weird tasting chicken . Only good part is it is open till 3 am . That's it . Not sure what to order if I have to visit again

I went in June based on a friend's recommendation-it was ok. Been to better dim sum places but it will do.  It was located in an old casino with low ceilings so prepare yourself if you dont like smoke while walking thru the casino.  The restaurant itself was bright n high ceiling with nice asian decore.  My husband n I arrived after 1 so our wait was not long but heard it normally is a long wait to get in.  I will go again next time to show my parents if we are close around but not a place i would go out of my way for.  Nothing on the dim sum menu stood out for me so i cant make any recommendations.
Tourist trap. Food is bland. Customer service is awful. Selection is poor. Prices are EXTREMELY HIGH for dim sum.

We walked over here from Palms at 10:30 Saturday morning. It was hot and we were hungry. Ordered a bunch of dim sum: Har gow, shu mai, shrimp rolled in flat noodles, fried shrimp ball with sugarcane, beef ribs, this vegetarian tofu dish, meatballs, steamed bbq pork buns, baked pork buns, green tea dessert (it had a mochi texture) and jasmine green tea. What a breakfast!

The dim sum is mediocre but the prices were moderate.. We were seated right away but after that there was no customer service whatsoever.. We had to ask multiple times for someone to bring us water and tea, something that is usually done right away without being requested.. The ladies that walk around with push carts kept asking if we wanted anything but how are we supposed to eat when the basics haven't been covered yet? I have never received such lack luster service from a dim sum restaurant.. I would probably return again if they improved their waitstaff but the likelihood of that is not likely.. Sorry but you'll just have to try again, because for now you fail..

Just came back from Vegas.  Got to try this dim sum place second time around and decided to write a review.  The dim sum tastes freshly made.  Flavor is good.  Price is reasonable.  Its located inside Gold Coast casino Las Vegas.  Get there for dim sum early, like around 10:30 -11:30.  It gets busy around noon and usually there is a line.  Cann't recommand anything specific.  Overall the food was good.  Will go there again next time in Vegas.

I've tried this place twice now for dim sum and both times it was excel. The venue is small with lots of people so be prepared for a bit of a wait or arrive early! Great selections, freshly made, the cart ladies are not pushy with their plates and dishes. Overall great food and experience.
The food was a bit Americanize to my liking, i had better authentic Chinese food at KJ's kitchen

I have mixed feelings about this place.  The food was pretty good, but the overall experience was kind of blah.

The restaurant itself is inside the Orleans, off to the side, and gated in,  but not really closed off from the casino.  There are paintings of happy Asian babies on the walls, and the clinking, and beeping of slot machines in the air.  The machines are only about 15 feet away, so there's cigarette smoke wafting in too.  

I very rarely drink soda, so when I do, I want it to be kind of special. There was nothing special about my watered down Pepsi.  :(
I told the server that the soda tasted off, and that the syrup needed to be changed.  He nodded, took my glass, ran off, and came back with the exact same crap, which kind of pissed me off.  Whatever.  We didn't come for the Pepsi.

Pot stickers:  These were really good. The wrappers were thicker than any pot stickers I've tried before.  They reminded me more of Russian pilmeni (I love those, so it worked out).

Hot and sour soup:  My boyfriend had a serious issue with this soup. He looked borderline pissed off after trying it.  It wasn't really spicy, or sour.  In fact, we were pretty sure it wasn't hot and sour soup, but the server assured us that it was.  I thought it tasted fine, but it wasn't what either of us expected, or craved. Lame.

Kung Pao chicken:  I thought this dish was great.  The chicken was juicy, all white meat, and perfectly sauced.  

Shanghai noodles:  The noodles were cooked well, and the vegetable ratio was nice.  The mushrooms in it were really tasty, but the pork was barely there.  It came in tiny half-inch slivers, thinner than the noodles themselves.  It was delicious, but it should have had more meat in it.

Overall, it was okay, but I doubt we'd come back.

While in vegas, our family friend who lives there recommended Ping Pang Pong in the Gold Coast Hotel and Casino since we were craving dimsum.  It was solid and pretty consistent for Dimsum. Fresh, the restaurant staff spoke Cantonese (which is the kind of Chinese that dimsum comes from). I give it a 4 because the dimsum is what I would expect out of a decent dimsum, but not AMAZING. For being in a hotel/casino, it's pretty good as well. Dimsum is usually either good or really bad. LOL It's tough to make it bad, but it happens quite a bit.  Whatever chinatown you go to, usually the crowded dimsum places are the best and having to wait in a line in vegas for dimsum meant Ping Pang Pong was decent and it was.  I would say it's a little bit above average.  

Also...I'd have to say...dimsum and blackjack is quite a kool combination ya? lol. Not to mention the sports betting section being right around the corner =P The hilarious chinese restaurant name is funny too =D

"the bomb . com" is how my friend described this place when she took me; she was right! Their dim sum is phenomenal -pork buns glazed with honey, shrimp in practically any form imaginable, and fantastic mango pudding for desert. My fav though were the pork spare ribs (my mouth is watering just thinking about them). Just be sure to come early since they get busy pretty early.

I was so adverse to coming to this place cuz of the stupid name for the restaurant until actual locals told me this place was one of the better casino restaurants for Chinese. Pretty damn good stuff.  I usually use my poker player points to pay for dinner here (side note..you want poker games with loads of reckless action..this is it!).  

Never made it for dim sum here..only dinner but it sure is good.  We probably come here once every 2 months or so which is actually a lot considering all the choices Vegas offers.

Sad to say, this is the best dim sum in Vegas.  I miss Seattle!  I have to tell ya -- the service (or lack of service) is why I gave this a "3 star".  The hostess is cute but she is completely an idiot!  Every 5 minutes while my mom and I waited in line, she would ask, "How many?"  I'm not kidding you -- There were only 4 of us in line (a couple ahead of us) -- and you'd think she would recognize four people, right?!  NOT!  Every 5 minutes, she'd ask, "How many?"   (Am I on "Seinfeld" or a candid camera?)  There were only 4 of us in line, and the hostess asked the couple ahead of us, "How many?"  They replied, "2" ... and then she turned to us and asked, "How many? 4?"  -- um,  helllooooooooooooooooo!!!!  My 3 year old niece can add better than her!  Anyway -- long story short, after 3 more times of "how many?" -- I finally lost my temper.  It's truly sad because the food is quite yummy -- it's just that the idiot hostess needs to get fired!  The funniest thing is, while I was enjoying my siew mai and har gow with mom, the idiot hostess sat a couple next to us.  Sure enough, the couple yelled at the hostess for her stupidity.  Wow!  I hope when I return, I don't have to answer to "How Many?"  10 times again.  LOL...

Went here on July 4th with family for dim sum.  This is the first time we've been to the new location inside the Gold Coast.  We arrived a little after 11:00 am and waited over an hour before being seated.  I just wish the wait would have been worth it-at least the service part.  For the most part the food was above average (4 stars), but the service was horrendous (1 star).  

Food
We had the following:  steamed chicken feet (good), baked bbq pork bun (very good), shrimp hargow (very good), fried sesame ball (very good), steamed pork spareribs (most of the pieces had too much fat), eggrolls (2 plates half had holes and were burnt, but good), baked egg tart (very good-only 2 on plate but they were big), sticky rice in lotus leaf (only 1 on plate and pretty bad-way toooooo much soy sauce or whatever sauce is part of it), rice noodle roll with shrimp (very good), and bean curd skin (horrible-way too much meat-it didn't taste normal-almost dumpling like, no bamboo shoots).

Service
For 3/4 of the plates we had, we had to flag people down get the food.  Once we asked for them to calculate our bill, it took about 10 minutes.  NEVER had to wait this long at any dim sum place to get bill.  Once I received the bill, I went to the front to pay.  There were two people up front handling the bills and payments.  No one was in line to pay but they were finishing ringing up the bill for another table.  I thought I would be next since I was just standing there waiting.  No.  One lady just started doing some other stuff, while I patiently waited.  This lady then went behind the screen and was given another bill and they processed this one before me-I'm just still standing there so I turned my back on them and looked out at the casino for about 2-3 minutes.  Finally, they said excuse me so I turned around and I thought that I can now finally pay my bill.  The other lady thought they were processing my bill, but the first lady said that it wasn't mine, so I had to wait another 30 seconds before they finally took my bill.

I don't expect very good service at Chinese restaurants, but the experience I had regarding the bill calculation and paying the bill takes my Chinese restaurant experience to a brand new low.

I had some time in between appointments and needed lunch.  Since I was alone and without my husband, who usually says "no asian food," I came here for Dim Sum.  When I used to work at Boeing I used to go to Top Gun in Bellevue and Imperial Garden in Renton a bit for Dim Sum and loved it, so I'm comparing this to those establishments.

I had one order of Shumai, one Shrimp Dumpling, one steamed  Pork Bun, and after I was full they had fried crab claws that I couldn't say no to.  I felt like I ate way too much food, even though the plates were tiny.  The Shumai was ok, it has nothing on Top Gun's Shumai which is my favorite ever.  The shrimp dumplings at Imperial Garden are also superior but these were good.  The real star of my meal here was those crab claws, though.  I really loved those which is why I feel Ping Pang Pong gets four stars.

So my husband, who isn't a real dim sum fan outside of baked pork buns, or a fan of Asian food in general because he never had it in his native alien territory of Montana, found out I went here and now wants to go, so I'm happy to say I will drag him here soon and get some of those crab claws again.
Not good. But cheap n dish size is quit big. Very crowded n don't know where the long line comes from.
Love the upgrade, last time I was there it was small and plain, but good was delicious. Now along with the awesome food a beautiful atmosphere and great and friendly staff.

Apparently this place has been rated Vegas' #1 Chinese restaurant a number of times and I know why! Despite being tucked away in the Gold Coast casino this place was packed with Chinese & English speakers alike. 
My boyfriend and I got the pot stickers which were incredible. The filling was way more flavorful and, well, filling, than other pot stickers I've had. Every bite had a nice amount of it.
We then shared the Night Market Fried Rice. Holy macaroni! A substantial plate of rice with a good amount of beef in it for $10?! The ingredients were fresh, providing a taste that was less heavy-laden than most fried rice. The beef was fresh as well - beef can sometime make my stomach go topsy-turvy, but it didn't this time - indicating quality beef cooked properly. 
I wish this place was in my hometown. I'd like to visit them regularly.

What a hidden gem. Ever since I saw dumpling restaurants on the Travel channel, I've wanted to try one. I don't know the correct terminology, so I apologize that I can't describe the experience more eloquently. 

Only available during lunch hours, little carts containing a vast variety of dumplings and other authentic foods circle around, going to each table. They open each lid and quickly describe what the container holds, you simply nod or say "no thank you". Whatever you chose is quickly put on your table, and the carts move on. It's very efficient and artistic in a way. 

Ok, the food itself: everything we had was good. My favorite was the steamed BBQ pork bun. I wish I had known a bit more, or would have been braver. It would have been great to have someone more familiar with the foods to help us , but I never felt unwelcome. Each server spoke English, and was nice. 

My only suggestion is that maybe they could have a menu for us newbies, so we could better understand what delicious little treats are hidden in each of those little pots. 

Pricing is very reasonable, hard to tell what each pot costs. They mark on a card each time you make a selection. I think we had 6 selections (each pot has about 3 dumplings). It was enough for 2 to share, and our bill was about $24.

Decent dim sum. I don't know of any other options in Las Vegas. When Vegas locals dine in, its probably a good bet Ping Pang Pong is considered one of the better places for dim sum. 

Make sure you get there early as there is a line during the rush hour. The dim sum is good the service is ok. We went in during the Sunday brunch crowd, a group of 10 and they sat us on two tables as my buddy (who is a Vegas local), was able to make a reservation for us. 

I loved their dim sum. You name it, Har Gow, Siu Mai, noodles, spare ribs, baos, etc...it was all pretty good. What sucked was the popular items such as the Har Gow (shrimp balls) and Siu Mai (steaming dumplings) always ran out. Every cart that rolled through all said "later". 

Yummy for Vegas standards....

Dim sum here is pretty good for a Vegas joint. However, I did not like the service! When my friend and I first got here (around 1130), we had to wait about 10-15 min before we could get some tea or even water to drink! It wasn't even that busy yet, and we were seated right away! Usually, at many dim sum places, it is automatic to get tea or water right away! Also, the carts did not come to our side very often, so we had to make sure to get plenty of things before we started really eating! (Especially the dessert cart! Geez! That one took forever to come by!).

The place is also pretty small. We can barely get into or out of our seats, since they were so close together (so I just stayed in mine the whole time without moving it heheh!). 

The only thing that I tried here that was not as common as other dim sum places was their soft tofu dessert with sugar/ginger syrup. It tasted like a Filipino dessert called Ta-ho (except Ta-ho is sweeter and not ginger-tasting). That was pretty good. They also had a seaweed salad, (which looked very good but didn't come until we were waiting for our check), and we couldn't try it! Other than those two, just your typical dim sum place with a limited quantity of items!

I probably would not go back here, especially if I ever have to wait! Geez...wait for a table...and then WAIT for a drink...and then WAIT for the dim sum...and even WAIT for our check/to go boxes! 

Unless you're with a big party, this place would probably be decent to have dim sum. Be ready to FLAG those cart people! Expect a wait on the weekends starting around 12 (We went on a Sunday). 

Btw, the price for most of the dim sum is about $3 a piece, so it could add up if you want to try lots of things...(They also charge for tea!)

I was excited to try this restaurant after I learned that locals frequent here for their chinese food fix. I came here twice during my trip to Vegas - once for dinner and once for dim sum. Both meals were delicious! Some of the memorable menu items included the fried chive cakes (I would be happy if my meal consisted entirely of this) and the lobster & vermacelli dish.

It can get a little busy during meal times, so if you want to avoid waiting in line, it is best to avoid popular eating times. We tried to go pretty early, so waiting in line wasn't too much of a problem. 

It is located in Gold Coast, so it is not as easy to access as some other places directly on the main part of the Strip. However, it is definitely worth going out of your way if you want to experience Chinese foods during your trip to Vegas.

Not your average Chinese restaurant inside a casino in Las Vegas. Ping Pang Pong (I laugh a little every time I say it) is legit dim sum and a la carte Chinese dishes located inside the Gold Coast Casino. 

We met friends who are regulars there and we really enjoyed our Sunday brunch. We ate siu mai, hargow, shredded pork dumplings, pork ribs in black bean sauce, sesame shrimp dumplings, house special fried rice and bbq pork buns. It was all good and I was surprised at how good the food was. I usually avoid eating Asian food inside a casino because it's usually a poor interpretation of the original cuisine but Ping Pang Pong is certainly the exception. Good, fresh dim sum served in carts the way they should be. There was a line to get seated but our friends were already there so we didnt have to wait, thankfully. 

I really enjoyed all the things we had. They were mostly the typical things we order at dim sum restaurants we frequent in LA & SF except for the sesame shrimp dumplings and the shredded pork dumplings. Those 2 I havent had before and I really liked them both. The sesame shrimp one was little shrimps stuffed in rolled puff pastry. It was great. The shredded pork dumplings were like stuffed to the brim potstickers. They were tasty and were perfect with a soy sauce dip.

Service was friendly. We didnt feel rushed and our table was attended to at all times. Our drinks were refilled and anything we requested (chili sauce, lemon, etc) were brought to us rather quickly. 

I highly recommend Ping Pang Pong when you're anywhere near the Gold Coast. Free parking and open til 3am!! What?!!

This place came highly recommended from our taxi cab driver and we were a bit skeptical.  He reassured us that the place had the best dim sum in town and everyone who ate there were Asian and he's pretty much the only white guy.  Not being racist, but that's a good sign!  

Food wise: The ladies come around in their carts and it's typical dim sum.  Some were good and some were re-steamed.  You can always tell because the shell at this point is a bit too mushy or it has a texture that you know it wasn't so fresh.  Nonetheless there was a good selection.

Atmosphere:  Yes, it can get packed and yes, there were a lot of Asians that dined here.  I almost felt like I was back in Hong Kong with people just talking super loud and being kinda rude.  Haha...

Bottom line: If dim sum is what you're looking for and you want something a little more authentic, this is an option.  I know the casinos on the strip has plenty of Asian restaurants, but it's more catered to the "tourists" crowd.  This feels a little more homey.

First of all, great name. Not a big fan of the old and smelly casino it was in. But they do have dim sum carts. Mostly Chinese who do not speak English had a hard time asking if pork was in certain dim sum or not. I thought the shrimp noodle was the best thing I tried. Something was odd about the fact they didn't have our favorite, har gow. It was interesting that they had boba and Thai tea but I'm sure some people would like that. Not fancy not extra nice nothing compared to more authentic style dim sum found in chinatowns around the world. There was a mix up on our order and they brought us the wrong dish which we didn't get charged for. Management was helpful. Everyone who ate there right after started complaining of stomach pains and side effects of too much msg in the food too... hmm..

This is my favorite authentic Chinese restaurant.  It's located in the Gold Coast Casino and every time I've eaten here, I'm the only customer ordering in English.  This is authentic!  You can order off the menu or eat Dim Sum off the various food carts being rolled around the restaurant.  Personally, I think it's better to skip the menu and order whatever looks good on the carts.  We ordered all kinds of items off the carts with beer and our bill was only $50.  Everything was delicious, except the fried chicken feet, which even our waitress said she did not eat.  You don't want the chicken feet, but everything else we had off the carts was delicious.  Be prepared to be a little overwhelmed when you first sit down by the various food cart servers pitching you with all kinds of different food choices.  Just choose whatever looks good and pass on anything that doesn't, and stop ordering when your table looks like it has enough food on it.  Authentic Chinese restaurant ambiance-5 stars, Food-5 stars, Service-5 stars, Value-5 stars.

I ordered the combination plate of bbq short ribs and crispy grilled pork.  Easily one of the better Vegas decisions made.  

Pork can go wrong for me but they nailed it, super tender with amazing complimentary sauces.

We come here because their "jook" rice congee is on point. Usually a pretty long wait to get seated. The dim sum price points are a little high for the portion that's served. But we visit here once in a while. Food is hot, delicious, and carts come by consistently.
I love it there they had the best sausage fried rice there I would go back everyone I come to Vegas and play

Great food but portions are small. The family ordered salt and pepper pork chops, walnut prawns, and bbq pork. Everything tasted great.  I gave 3 stars because the service needs work. Our waitress had us (as well as her other tables)  waiting for the check forever.  We got tired of waiting so we finally went up front to pay...still had to wait because they were so slammed with calls/ pick up orders. Other than that small issue, everything else was fine.

My sister and brother-in-law are huge fans of this place.  They rave about it all the time and every time they are in Vegas they have to go here at least once. Thus, I was excited to finally try this place out.  However, it certainly did not live up to their hype.

Ping Pang Pong is located in the Gold Coast Hotel & Casino.  They serve dim sum from 10am to 3pm and reopen for dinner from 5pm to 3am.  We were able to catch dinner last Sunday.  Wait time was not bad at all.  However, service was not the best.  It was such a hassle to ask for anything besides placing our order.

We ended up ordering fried flounder fish, snow pea leaves with roasted garlic, and the satay beef with enoki mushrooms and pineapple.  Every thing was served family-style and arrived fairly quickly.  The fried flounder and pea leaves are things they always order.  It does not have strong flavors, but when paired with the dipping sauce it certainly hits the spot for a good home-cooked meal.  The satay beef, however, was beyond greasy.  I swear eating it can cause bad heartburns.

This place is definitely not a must when visiting Vegas, but not bad if you are in the area and want authentic Chinese food.

Two friends and I dined at Ping Pang Pong this week for dinner, and our expectations could not have been higher. I lived in China briefly and one of my accompanying friends is from the Philippines and her mother makes incredible Asian cuisine. So, when we heard that PPP was one of the most authentic and well-received Chinese restaurants in America, we couldn't wait to try it.

Immediately, I was pleased with our server, who noticed we were ordering things without meat and asked if we were vegetarians. We said yes, and she informed us that many of the items were cooked with chicken broth, but said she'd ensure it wasn't used in our dishes. Unfortunately, we concluded that the chicken broth must be Ping Pang Pong's top secret ingredient, because we were rather disappointed in our food! It pains me to say I've had better tasting meals at Panda Express.

Here's what we ordered and my thoughts on it:
-Wrinkled Green Beans: Bland, but nothing a little extra hot sauce couldn't fix. 
-Ma Po Tofu: Good seasoning but we would have preferred a firmer tofu over the squishy one.
-Sauted Lotus Root: The fact it was described as "pungent" on the menu should have been a red flag. It was too crunchy and the taste of vinegar was over-whelming.
-Shanghai Noodles: We got it without the pork, and it was basically oily ramen. Big portions a plus, though.
-Rice: Dried out and hard!  
-Iced Chrysanthemum tea: It was akin to drinking potted plant water.
-Fresh Coconut Juice: It was on the menu, but apparently not available. I hate it when that happens.

Ultimately, I was disappointed with Ping Pang Pong and don't plan on returning. Another patron might have better luck ordering Dim Sum or a meat dish, as apparently both have been praised. However, I'll stick to other establishments/fly to China the next time I want authentic noodles/have my friend's mom cook for me! :D

You win some then you dim sum. One of my favorite Sunday morning meals. I have dim sum regularly and this is my favorite place in Las Vegas. They recently renovated making the restaurant a lot of fancy, classy, and larger (holds like triple what it use to) than before. The line for this restaurant can get long but it moves pretty fast. I don't remember the names of any of the dim sum dishes I got, but all the favorites are great here. I always end the meal with some egg tarts. Overall I'll continue to come here.

This has got to be one of the best dim sum and Chinese dishes I've had in a while. I'm also visiting from Salt Lake City, UT where Dim sum is limited,  so trust me on this one. This brightly lit restaurant will catch anyone's eyes when walking through Gold Coast Casino. For a party of 5 around 845pm Saturday night, we were seated within 10 minutes. 

Maybe the carts only come around during lunch, but for dinner services, you order from the menu. We ordered family style to try a little bit of everything. 

----Entree----
Singapore noodles: a little too salty for me, but overall, great flavors.
Beef flat noodles: saucy and soft pieces of beef. Delicious! 
Three mushrooms: my favorite dish because of the shiitaki mushrooms.
Calamari with lotus root in XO sauce: calamari is great, but I wasn't a fan of the lotus root. It's got the crunchy texture of a water chestnut, except it's bigger.
Salt and pepper pork chop: just order this. It's so good! Crunchy texture on the outside and soft pork. Just be careful you don't chomp down on the bone thinking it's the crunchy layer......like me 

----Dim Sum----
Shu mai: oh it's the best I've had! 
Chicken feet: it almost melts in your mouth. Then you gotta spit out the chicken bones.
Har gow (shrimp dumpling): can't go wrong ordering these
Steamed pork buns: these are my dessert when I eat dim sum!

This place is a disaster!

We went on a Sunday Night for dinner. They have a big dim sum service on Sunday morning/afternoon which basically leaves them with no food on Sunday night. We tried to order appetizers, but they literally did not have any left. NONE! No spring rolls, no potstickers, nothing! Seriously people, if you are out of food close the restaurant, don't stay open and disappoint your customers because they can't order what they want.

As for the foods that they did have, my sister ordered the duck, I ordered the orange chicken, my brother-in-law ordered a brisket thing and our friend ordered the chicken chow mein. The cooks all make different foods and don't sync up the food to come out at the same time. So when an entree is done they bring it out to your table, even if the other entrees aren't ready yet. The duck came first, it was a few minutes before the orange chicken came out, and then another 5 minutes at least before the chow mein came out. This would be fine it you are eating family style and everyone is sharing everything, but if you are ordering and eating your own entree like we were it creates a big problem. You can either be rude and eat your food while it's hot, or be polite and wait for everyone to get their food while yours gets cold.

You will notice that I said my brother-in-law ordered a brisket something but I didn't mention when it got delivered. That's because we never got it! Another problem with the way they bring the food out is if they forget something, you just kind of assume it's still coming, and you don't think to ask about it. Our waitress never ordered the brisket, and we didn't discover this until it was too late.

As for the food itself, my sister was happy with the duck, but I didn't try it as duck is not my thing. The orange chicken was okay, but I've had much better.

Obviously being as our server forgot to order one of our entrees I'm not going to give the service a very high mark. Additionally, the atmosphere of the restaurant was really bad. It's located in the casino, very close to all the slot machines and casino action and as a result is very loud. It's a small space and they try to cram as many people in as possible so its very cramped and uncomfortable.

So to review, the food is bland but okay, the service and atmosphere sucks and if you go on Sunday night (and I would assume Saturday too) expect them to be out of everything.

Passable Dim Sum. Probably the best Dim Sum in Vegas but not in the Western United States. I know it is not fair to compare to LA standards but it has to be compared to some standard.

A lot of the items were cold, such as XO sauce rice noodles and Chinese broccoli. The roast pork tasted reheated. The Har Gow and Shrimp Cheung Fun were good. If you are dying for dim sum in Vegas, this is the place to go.

Good dim sum in Vegas that's open late. It's located inside a casino which was only 4 minutes from our condo. We came here around 11 in the afternoon and there was already a line forming. 
The wait wasn't too bad if you have someone in your group wait while you go gamble lol and switch off whenever.

The dim sum was fresh, hot and delicious! The egg custard for dessert is really good and wasn't too overly sweet. The only downside was the ladies pushing the carts because it took them forever to come around the restaurant. Other than that everything was fine and service was friendly.

Came here with a friend for a dim sum lunch late Monday morning, and it was already packed with a short line of customers waiting.  The wait was about 15 minutes before we were seated at a table.

Service here is decent, with about 4 to 5 carts of dim sum items to choose from.  Selection was good, but the quality of the dim sum is both good and bad.  Good is good, not great, as the dishes we enjoyed didn't wow us tremendously.  The bad dishes, unfortunately, left a lasting impression.  The included the following:

- Roast Pork - Though the skin was rather crispy, you can tell by the color and texture of the meat that it was reaheated.  It was not fresh despite the fact the cart lady chimed that the roast pork just came out of the oven/fire.

- Siu Mai - These steamed dumplings are traditionally made with seasoned ground pork, shitake mushrooms and shrimp.  There was no shrimp in these, and some of the siu mais were prepared in the way where a couple of them were dense, dry and hard to the chew.  

- Chinese Broccoli - The dish we got had broccoli that was not as thick as the ones on the other dish.  Chinese Broccoli, as it grows older, the stalks get thicker and the inside turns from translucent (tender) to white (old).  We needed some greens to balance the meal and tried this.  Aside from the issue with the age of the broccoli used, the preparation was fine.  But older broccoli is harder to chew through and can be awfully fibrous.

- XO Sauce Pan-Fried Rice Noodle Rolls - Seasoned well, but could have used more XO Sauce to give it a spicy kick.  The problem with the dish we got was that it was the last of it's type on a cart, uncovered, and must have sat on that cart for awhile.  It was cold, not as flavorful, and cold rice noodles dry up and harden.  Best to ask to test the temperature of the plate or dish these more exotic dim sum dishes are served on so that you can figure out if it's relatively fresh, or if it's been sitting around for a while.

Prices are higher, as expected, since this is a hotel restaurant.  With other dim sum palaces in Vegas, we probably won't be back.  It's OK to good, but there are better.

Ping Pang Pong!!!

No we weren't here for a ping pong tournament nor were we in China neither!

We actually planned to eat here for a New Year's Eve dinner prior to playing the midnight bingo at Gold Coast Casino. I checked Yelp prior and the reviews appeared to be decent. 

When it comes to Chinese food and being Chinese-American, you can say I'm pretty picky. My older sister is even more so as she can cook some amazing Chinese dishes plus growing up with the two parents who both can whip out the best traditional Chinese dishes. My dad actually taught my mother to cook to begin with! I unfortunately never had any interest in learning to cook and I totally regret that now!

I had ordered quite a few entrees. The Gobo beef, Walnut shrimp, Ma po tofu, chicken with veggies, Singapore noodles and grilled lamb appetizers plus bowls of white rice which cost extra. What's up with that? We also had oolong tea and water. 

The only thing I was Totally, Totally amazed with was the quickness of us receiving our food!!! It was like minutes of ordering and open & close your eyes they appeared!!! Am I dreaming or what? No it actually happened and I saw it happened at several other tables surrounding us too.

My favorite entree was the gobo beef. I wished I ordered several of those as I could have had the entire plate to myself! I will definitely remember that for next time:)

This restaurant was closed between 3-5 pm so we had waited for a minimum of an hour for it to open. There was a huge line for both the to-go line and waiting to be served line for the restaurant prior to 5 pm.  They didn't have a special NYE up-charged menu which was nice unlike many others restaurants who did especially for NYE night. That's probably why they did so well that evening as they were extremely BUSY!!! Despite that fact the food still came out in record time.

I have to admit the food was quite tasty. Maybe a slight difference in taste but not bad though that I would knock down in stars. Our server was so busy that she disappeared for awhile as we needed to pay and leave.

You know we will be back. Probably with an updated version so that I can update my review to five stars!

Food: dim sum. Surprisingly authentic considering its located inside a casino. They had all our favorites so I liked that (har gow, bbq pork noodle, baked custard bun, steamed rice in banana leaf, pai gu, etc.) I did not care for their lobo gao - it just didn't taste freshly cooked.

Service: pretty good as chinese restaurants go! Ha ha. Carts and our jasmine tea were brought around fast and our check was handled quickly. When I asked for soy sauce they brought it. Can't ask for more people!

Location: inside the Gold Coast Casino. Restaurant is a bit small so I would not bring a big group here. (i.e. 5 people or more). We went on a weekday around 11am and it was a full restaurant.

Came here really late after the Penn and Teller show at Rio's and we were craving dim sum.
Not very good...
Some of the dishes, like the siu mai weren't fresh, maybe from the previous night...
Some of the dishes that came out didn't seem authentic, one was wrapped in a tortilla...?
Another was also odd, "gold sand bun" or something, it was a little sweet bun with sugar in the middle... Never had that before and I don't recommend it.
A couple things they did get right, but I can't remember which dishes because they were just right, not exceptional.

We may have gone at a bad time because every time we walked past it (over the next few days) there were long lines for the restaurant.

The best thing about this place is the name: PING PANG PONG! One more time: PING PANG PONG! I was told by the owner that it means "hockey puck" in English, which makes zero sense for a Chinese restaurant in Las Vegas. That said, the service was fast and friendly and the food was better than expected: a tad on the greasy side, but it's in the Gold Coast Casino so I was just happy there weren't cigarette butts in it.

First time here... came for dim sum
Prices seemed very reasonable for Vegas... most of our dishes were the medium price of $2.88.
We liked most of the dishes, except for the siu mai- too many orange fish eggs on top and it didn't look appetizing, nor did it taste all that great.

Possibly the best Chinese restaurant in Las Vegas featuring authentic dishes plus dim sum.  The new location inside the Gold Coast Hotel & Casino is definitely an upgrade with higher ceilings and apparently double the space of previous location.  Seems like the move eliminates the long lines of people waiting for a table.  Best dim sum in Las Vegas with fresh food served via tableside carts including the shrimp har gow and pork shumai...standards at dim sum.  Don't get seated in the big dining room with carpet because the carts aren't able to move in there which made it quite annoying to walk to the carts to pick food out.  

I recommend ordering from the menu for dinner since dim sum ends around 3 pm.  All dishes are very flavorful and authentic, mostly Cantonese in my opinion.  Must try include the lamb chop appetizer, egg white fried rice, salt and pepper pork chops, green beans with XO sauce.  These are just a few recommendations but the menu has a dish for every palette!

My friend recommended that we try Ping Pang Pong as he said it's the best Chinese in Las Vegas.  We stopped by Wednesday evening and were seated immediately.

My dinner, the orange beef, was good.  Not great, but good.  Everyone else liked their meals as well -- two different fried rice dishes and also Mongolian beef.  The service had a couple of hiccups -- one order came out wrong, which they did offer to fix.  Also, we never received any rice for either of the beef entrees.

I think the real charm of this place may come from the Dim Sum lunch menu or maybe the more "authentic" dishes.  But for those of us with Americanized taste buds, Ping Pang Pong is A-OK.

man! this place smokes about 1/2 the chinese restaurants on spring mountain!! the food is DELICIOUS here! very authentic!! chinese cooks, chinese waiters, and a bunch of chinese people inside the restaurant! you know it's good chinese food when you see a whole gang of chinese people in there chowing down!! besides the full menu, during the day, they serve dim sum! i've been here a few times and have always ordered the chinese sausage fried rice (which is made with egg whites and thinly sliced chinese broccoli steams) and salt & pepper pork chops! my boyfriend and i went on valentine's day this past monday and i decided to venture out and order the wonton noodle soup!! that was not a disappointment... the broth was delicious and the wontons were very plump with pork & shrimp. kind of reminded me of the wonton noodle soup in hong kong!! i can bet that 1/2 of the cooks came straight from hong kong! the style of cooking there is very very very cantonese! definitely will bring family there when they come into town next time.... sorry sam woo... i found a new joint!! PING PANG PONG! i love saying that name!! LOL hahahahhaha! OH! 1 more thing... they are open until 3am!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Stay away from this place.  Ordered the Chinese broccoli and there was two caterpillars in the veggie.  Told the manager/owner about it and he asked me, " What do you want me to do about it? Sometimes veggies have caterpillars and it's normal. " I was stunned that he can even say that.  How about wash your veggies properly.  I asked for his name and the staff will not say.  We paid and left.  Called Gold Coast to file a complaint and they can't do anything about it because they are independently owned.  If I could... I would rate Ping Pang Pong a negative 10 stars.

Black chicken with black dates soup is friggin special. Also I like that they don't bring me forks. That's super offensive if they bring forks. Why? Because even Japanese restaurant know better they don't bring you a fork to eat sushi. 

***WARNING Don't pay attention about yelpers complaining about service. This is not PF CHANGS, or Applebee's.***

The entry level dim sum is good (KJ Kitchen at the RIO makes the simple stuff better currently--- their LO Bak Go is so er mah gawd!). Reading other reviews on here is so funny because of complaints about service. Want to be seated? Wave some one down, ask loud, better yell it in Cantonese. Don't expect them to ask if you want water or soda. Expect tea and only tea, unless you wave someone down and ask loud for cold water, same with refills. (Although they do bring you large water glasses and it tastes good. As a kid growing up Chinese, I used to think they scoop the water out of the fish tanks because it did taste a bit fish. That must be because they keep the ice machine behind the fish tanks. No fish tanks at PING PANG PONG hahahaha.)

 Bring someone Chinese with you if you are scared. Want more tea, shit you know what you have to do with the lid. Want to pay your check? Lift it in the air  "Maihdaan!!!!" or go up to the Cashier and start picking your teeth with the tooth picks.

If there is old food lingering on your new plates... I wipe that shit off with hot tea and napkin.

What kind of service do people need? 

If I read one more review about Orange Beef.... If you go in there ordering General Tso's expect bad service. Tea, take dirty dishes away, bring my food. It's all good in the Chinese hood. If you're scared go to Elephant bar, Jose or Sean Jean will make you something nice there. I'm not racist I eat black chicken. 

Seriously about the service, you can have a good ole' dim sum time without making at the least bit eye contact. Oh and lastly, I think I read a review about hot mustard... do they have hot mustard? Hahahahahahahahahahahahahahaha. I'm not going to answer that expect a hahahahaha if you ask. 

No seriously eating dim sum is not that hard. I'm just making fun. I gotta go piss off Japanese people by rubbing my wooden chopsticks together down the street while I contemplate what's so delicious about Teriyaki. 

Ho Sek Ah!

Didn't want even leave 1 star- called earlier in the day to make reservations & said I didn't need one. Stood in line for an hour with parties in front of us (which were not happy either) Eventually gave up and ate elsewhere.

This is definitely a hidden gem hidden in a corner of the Gold Coast casino. But once we were there, man was the line long! This must mean that the food is good. We waited about 45 minutes to be seated which is why I give it 4 stars. 

The food was all really delicious! I love their chicken feet, they were surprisingly really huge and juicy. We ordered the classic hagow/shumai which was also fresh and delicious. I was waiting for their shrimp rolls, but unfortunately, it took awhile for that to come, and when I asked one of the lady's who was pushing the cart, she seemed very irritated and started yelling back at me, which caught me off guard. But other than that, the food is great, and the price is decent. I know where to go now to get my dim sum fix when I'm back in Vegas!
One of my favorite Chinese in town. Worth the long wait in line. Prices increased since move to new location. I always crave the fried rice, simple yet so delicious.

In all my years of coming to Las Vegas I never knew really good and authentic Chinese food even existed here. Like others have mentioned, this certainly is a hidden gem.

A couple of friends attending the jewelry trade show at the Mandalay had invited me to a nice quiet high end dinner at the Jasmine Restaurant at the Bellagio when , just as we were about to leave for the Bellagio, my friend received a business call saying their business contacts wanted to invite us for dinner instead.....and were too afraid to decline. All I knew was that I was asked to get in the car and just follow the leader.

Being the fish out of water, I didn't speak a or understand a word of Chinese and had no idea what the plan was. We eventually ended up off the strip at some big stand alone casino across from the Palms Hotel and Casino.
